text:
Speaking at our #RCGPLive event on Omicron, @GaryHowsam encouraged practices to review business continuity plans as many GP practices experience increased demand on services and will also have staff deployed elsewhere in the NHS. 

Watch the event back: https://t.co/QVSqRx0ftP https://t.co/l0CsFLFoCB

Also among GPs receiving #NewYearsHonours are former @rcgp_ni Chair @GrainneRCGP OBE, College prescribing lead @TonyAvery1 OBE, @RCGP_SYNT Provost @AmarRughani MBE and Ethics Chair @SimonDGregory MBE - congratulations!
Lots of GPs being recognised for their work in the #NewYearsHonours - many congratulations to former Chair @HelenStokesLam who has received a Damehood for services to general practice.
Happy New Year ü•≥ to all our Members, Fellows and their teams!

Listen back to @michael_mul1 on @TimesRadio earlier (1h48m): ‚ÄúIt was a huge challenge landed on us, on top of all the other things we have to do in general practice to ensure patients get the care they need - but GPs, our teams and volunteers stepped up‚Äù https://t.co/90JDajmK9e

‚ÄúStaff absence in general practice is a significant issue. Staff need access to tests to enable them to get back to work as soon as safely possible. But we also need investment in tech to allow well staff who are isolating to work remotely where appropriate‚Äù @MartinRCGP @SkyNews

‚ÄúThings are busy in general practice and we‚Äôre expecting them to get even busier over the next couple of weeks. It‚Äôs not just Covid, it‚Äôs people who are sick with other things and patients living with long term conditions‚Äù @MartinRCGP tells @SkyNews https://t.co/BZhTUYLGyo

General practice doesn't have access to the same levels of data on staff absence as secondary care. Help us build a picture of the situation in general practice by filling out our brief survey: https://t.co/mNgaimvfcn @MartinRCGP

Watch out for @MartinRCGP on @SkyNews shortly discussing the efforts of GPs and their teams delivering the #COVIDBooster vaccine over the last few weeks, and pressures on general practice due to increasing levels of absence due to sickness and/or having to isolate

At last week's #RCGPLive event on Omicron @NikkiKF welcomed our updated workload prioritisation guide to support practices as the new variant spreads & GP efforts shift to deliver the COVID-19 booster prog

Guidance https://t.co/wMbKqootqw
Watch the event https://t.co/QVSqRx0ftP https://t.co/wjWLe21416

Do you look after patients in contact with the criminal justice system? Our eLearning course on secure environments will increase your confidence in managing complexity, safe prescribing, and partnership when working inside a prison. Learn more > https://t.co/UjUkmtnVz4 https://t.co/0Ye1FiFoYT

It's important to prioritise delivering the COVID-19 booster vaccine at the moment as "we have a narrow window of opportunity" - @CMO_England at last week's  #RCGPLive discussion on Omicron & what it means for general practice.

Watch the event back: https://t.co/bqVGJj62Vu https://t.co/MBYWU2yjog

As Omicron continues to spread rapidly, "GP practices are experiencing high levels of staff off-sick, much higher than usual" - Vice Chair @GaryHowsam on some key findings from a recent RCGP survey at our #RCGPLive event on Omicron 

Watch the event back https://t.co/bqVGJj62Vu https://t.co/vYsTH9xKOY

Merry Christmas to all our members celebrating today üéÑMany, along with their teams and #PrimaryCare colleagues - and colleagues right across the #NHS - will be working hard today and throughout the festive season protecting and delivering care to patients. Thank you.

At our #RCGPLive event on Omicron earlier this week, NHSE Director of Primary Care @NikkiKF took the opportunity to recognise the leading role that general practice has taken to consistently deliver the COVID-19 vaccine prog. 

Watch the event back here: https://t.co/bqVGJj62Vu https://t.co/xMketgYLH9
Watch Professor @MartinRCGP on @SkyNewsAust discussing the response of general practice to the Omicron variant in the UK and progress with the booster rollout https://t.co/39NUrYoR03

Yesterday during our #RCGPLive discussion on Omicron and what it means for general practice,  @CMO_England acknowledged the "amazing work" that general practice has done over the last two years & continues to do. 

Watch the event back here: https://t.co/93ObZn1sOa https://t.co/inAOKoqZa5
#RCGPLive: That's all for today and don't worry if you missed out, you can watch it back here: https://t.co/nC1FKHuYdj
#RCGPLive: @d_spiegel says that facts alone won't convince everybody to get vaccinated, openness and transparency about information is absolutely necessary to counter any hesitancy

#RCGPLive: @NikkiKF thanked GP for stepping up once again to deliver the COVID-19 booster prog  & encouraged practices to use quieter days as opportunities to vaccinate people that may appreciate a quieter environment eg those with severe mental illness or learning disabilities

#RCGPLive: @NikkiKF emphasised that GP remains open & thanked the College & @theBMA for producing guidance around workload prioritisation so practices can safely & confidently focus on care that needs to be delivered in the coming weeks. Take a look: https://t.co/MKg4VJYiuu
#RCGPLive: @GaryHowsam highlighted data from an RCGP survey from the last 24hrs which shows that 95% of respondents are experiencing high levels of staff off sick, worse than usual.
#RCGPLive: @CMOEngland warned that #Omicron is spreading at "extraordinary speed" which is already impacting the supply side of healthcare as more staff are getting infected or having to isolate
#RCGPLive: @CMO_England begins by thanking the profession and acknowledging the "absolutely amazing" work that general practice has done in the last two years and is continuing to do

#RCGPLive: in the next few minutes, @MartinRCGP will kick off our panel discussion with @CMO_England @NikkiKF @d_spiegel @GaryHowsam on #Omicron and what it means for general practice. Will you be joining us? https://t.co/NQ77U2Of09 https://t.co/IVWMOxHVHY

üì¢ TONIGHT 18:30 üì¢

Ask our panel @MartinRCGP @CMO_England, @NikkiKF, @d_spiegel, & @GaryHowsam using #RCGPLive & watch live tonight üëá

https://t.co/Oj82Xp4lpP https://t.co/G87sb2s1Gi

And check out updated guidance from @rcgp and @TheBMA on workload prioritisationüëâhttps://t.co/OIWg2XRd83

And hear from RCGP Vice Chairs Dr @GaryHowsam and Dr Margaret Ikpoh @docmagsy on how GPs can pivot to support the accelerated vaccination booster campaign, reprioritise workload, and plan for business continuity
Get insights into interpreting the data with renowned statistician Prof Sir David Spiegelhalter @d_spiegel
Hear from the @CMO_England on what we know about #Omicron so far and what this means for GPs

Join the conversation tomorrow evening to discuss the implications of #Omicron for general practice with @CMO_England @d_spiegel @GaryHowsam and @docmagsy chaired by @MartinRCGP 

üëâPut your questions to the panel using #RCGPLive
üëâWatch live at 18:30 https://t.co/0OqYfoH8t7 https://t.co/6GldDN91i8

@MartinRCGP @CMO_England @d_spiegel @GaryHowsam Join the #RCGPLive conversation tomorrow evening to put your questions to our panel where we'll discuss the implications of Omicron on GP workload, prioritisation, vaccinations & more

Please note given the rapidly changing situation speakers may be called away to other business
Read @MartinRCGP's response to the new study on 'frequent attenders' at general practice, and why continuity of care is so important: https://t.co/BrnjUNxMYY https://t.co/YLiDEXAKBy

Children with life-limiting conditions face significant challenges when they transition from paediatric to adult care. Our latest eLearning blog, based around our eLearning course developed with @Tog4ShortLives, focuses on the role of primary care: https://t.co/5HVJrffMr4 https://t.co/9P3iMHCZzi

UPDATED GUIDANCE: alongside @TheBMA we have updated our workload prioritisation guide to support practices in their planning, as the #Omicron variant continues to spread and general practice pivots to deliver the accelerated COVID-19 booster campaign: https://t.co/MKg4VJYiuu

Join us for an important #RCGPLive next Wednesday to discuss Omicron and what it means for general practice. Chaired by @MartinRCGP  with panellists @CMO_England
@d_spiegel @GaryHowsam. Watch live on 22 Dec 18:30 https://t.co/IPffCxQWym. Submit your questions using #RCGPLive https://t.co/UqZRmt1hJ5
Read our letter to the @spectator, published yesterday, responding to claims about general practice made in an article earlier this month.   https://t.co/iAz5xV8GcW https://t.co/PYwxUWapOP

Last chance to save 20% on delegate fees for the UK's largest event focused on the management of people with drug and alcohol problems in primary care. Earlybird rate ends 20 December. Register now: https://t.co/E3As7R6y4H https://t.co/ZYUvoVilsw

We're supporting the #NotTooMuchToMask initiative from @NHSConfed - No one wants another national lockdown or for the NHS to become overwhelmed this winter. Read this thread to find out more: https://t.co/6oV9aA59XP

We are still in a global pandemic and we can all help to stop the spread of the virus and reduce the risk of illness. After all, it‚Äôs #NotTooMuchToMask

Find out more about the @NHSConfed campaign. https://t.co/obzyHZPrFY

Our recent, free Essential Knowledge Update Hot Topic examines prescribing of NSAIDs, opioids, and paracetamol for #osteoarthritis, including the safest treatments for patients with comorbidities or for long-term use. Learn more now > https://t.co/xiXY4pvFxp

Follow in the footsteps of our accredited Active Practices, and your patients could see improved wellbeing, leading to a reduction in medication and a drop in social isolation. It's FREE and we'll support you with resources, hints and tips. Sign up now: https://t.co/XtKqWX350v https://t.co/u8P1EDfTs8

Our new Essential Knowledge Update Hot Topic focuses on non-specific symptom-based pathways for diagnosing less common cancers in primary care. Read more: https://t.co/RAiZO7Ht7v https://t.co/1vSANQDMs5

Read the College's latest riposte to columns in @theTelegraph by Patrick O‚ÄôFlynn and J. Meirion Thomas about 'part time working' in general practice. Also published as an abridged version in today's paper: https://t.co/gEEbcDnze3

A very small proportion of patients with symptoms of otitis externa will have malignant otitis externa, a more serious condition which requires same day #ENT review. Watch our latest Five Minutes to Change your Practice screencast to learn more: https://t.co/osGUxeCN1R https://t.co/1U6KlIziQ3

Our new campaign with @CruseSupport launched this week, is to ensure both GPs and grieving patients feel supported when it comes to discussing bereavement. Read more about it and the resources available here: https://t.co/5BJeZzSz3H
Dr @GaryHowsam said choices will have to be made "as to where we add most clinical value" #COVIDBooster  https://t.co/QGw5nM2lRQ

The @TARGETabx toolkit respiratory tract infection (#RTI) resource suite contains lots of helpful materials to use with patients throughout the winter, including pictorial leaflets and guidance for OOH consultations. Learn more: https://t.co/U1hSDiN0JA #KeepAntibioticsWorking https://t.co/yeW3ucKryM

So that we can divert resources to the vaccination programme alongside our clinical workload, "we‚Äôre calling for a reduction in bureaucracy, regulatory processes, and tick-box exercises that offer no real clinical value." Dr @GaryHowsam #TodayProgramme

While GPs are under immense pressure, "from what we know, our best bet to reduce the consequences of the virus moving forward is to maximise the #BoosterJab numbers - our teams are ready to support the programme as we did earlier on in the year." Dr @GaryHowsam #TodayProgramme

"GPs are already working at full capacity and if we‚Äôre going to have to divert our attention to the vaccine programme again, then there‚Äôs going to have to be some choices made about where we add clinical value" Dr @GaryHowsam #COVIDBooster #TodayProgramme
Listen to Dr @GaryHowsam speaking to the @BBCr4today programme about the kind of support GPs will need to deliver the expanded COVID booster programme https://t.co/aUlvSvgvZC (from 1:09)

Featured eLearning: Secure environments. This new course is aimed at those working with patients in the criminal justice system. Improve your understanding of the prison context including factors that influence patient safety. Access course > https://t.co/UjUkmtnVz4 https://t.co/QbPTr2zQ85

Would you like to develop your leadership skills and expertise in obesity? We're looking for qualified, practising GPs to join a FREE specialist programme to drive improvements in the management of obesity nationwide. Learn more > https://t.co/s7sXufBpcg https://t.co/ExEPUNpXzx
Listen to RCGP Vice Chair Dr @GaryHowsam discuss the GP role in the extended COVID vaccine booster programme on @BBCr4today shortly after 7am this morning.

Watch RCGP Vice Chair, @GaryHowsam on @SkyNews live at 3.30pm discussing the expansion of the Covid booster programme and what support GPs need to deliver it, including a suspension of time-consuming bureaucratic demands such as QOF.
At 2pm Dr @GaryHowsam will be speaking to @BBCNewsChannel  about the expansion of the Covid vaccination programme. Watch here: https://t.co/B2bo2QEqMF

Have you seen our new Essential Knowledge Update Hot Topic? Based on trials with more than 100,000 participants, it looks at the effectiveness and safety of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), opioids, and paracetamol for osteoarthritis: https://t.co/RAiZO7Ht7v https://t.co/99hpSmhdav

We're delighted to have newly accredited 84 GP practices this month as Veteran Friendly. It's free and easy to sign up and requires no additional time commitment. Join today to provide the very best care for veteran patients and their families: https://t.co/Y27hH1XIL6 https://t.co/FcthAXBsE4

Delighted to be back with the second in our Clinical Hot Topics conferences focusing on issues affecting ethnic minority patients. A rousing keynote from RCGP President @claregerada and fantastic first session with @HealthactiveGB on cultural nutrition #RCGPPatientDiversity2021

Today's @NHSDigital data on GP appointments shows general practice is getting 'busier and busier' as winter approaches. More than 30m patient consultations were made in general practice in England in October. Read our full response:
https://t.co/HWUhrgaHUD

Kawasaki disease is 40% more likely to be diagnosed between December and March each year. In the UK, it is more commonly found in children of African descent. To find out more about diagnosis and referral, take a look at our free eLearning course: https://t.co/KERO2G5wy2

üéÖ GPs and practice teams signed up to our Active Practice Charter are getting moving in lots of simple, fun ways. Active Advent is a brilliant example! üéÑ Read more from Dr Hamish Grant and join him and the Chorley Surgery team to move more this December: https://t.co/Sdg51axt0v https://t.co/xybLJghmQv

Have you taken our free eLearning course on child and adolescent obesity? We look at the effects that the diseases of overweight and obesity have on children as they grow into adults, treatment options available now and how these may develop in the future: https://t.co/nmVlBBqHzp https://t.co/fHpv08eVMO

Are you familiar with the most common patient questions and misunderstandings around delayed prescriptions for #antibiotics? The free @targetabx TARGET Antibiotics Toolkit has guidance for GPs on this and lots more: https://t.co/dpSsC8NLkH #WAAW #AMR https://t.co/TnzVq1RaZR

Disappointing that this amendment was rejected in parliament today. Workforce planning is key to the sustainability of our NHS & the #HealthAndCareBill¬†was an opportunity for action. We urgently need more GPs & other HCPs and will continue to call for this to be addressed by govt https://t.co/uF3hNby6uL

Osteoarthritis most commonly affects #knee and #hip joints in older people. Our new, free Essential Knowledge Update Hot Topic explores the effectiveness and safety of NSAIDs, opioids, and paracetamol for knee and hip #osteoarthritis. Learn more: https://t.co/RAiZO7Ht7v https://t.co/bq0dAssOrG

Sign up now to get an early bird rate for our 2022 Managing Drug & Alcohol Problems in Primary Care event. We'll share the most up-to-date information on interventions for the prevention, assessment and treatment of alcohol and drug problems. Register: https://t.co/E3As7R6y4H https://t.co/1weW6XqpHH

Have you used any of the FREE resources in the new-look @targetabx TARGET Antibiotics Toolkit? Relaunched earlier this month, it has brand new guidance on discussing antibiotics with patients in general practice: https://t.co/yBvm8HXhzz #WAAW #HandleWithCare https://t.co/oW1dHPeUQq

Listen to RCGP Clinical Champion for veterans' health, Dr Veronica Grant on @GPonlinenews podcast discussing the College's work to support GPs caring for veterans, including the Veterans Friendly Accreditation Programme: https://t.co/h7fUIN5swC. More info: https://t.co/xQvs9dLH3P
#RCGPCouncil comes to a close. Next meeting in February 2022.
.@MartinRCGP summarises some of the key policy and campaigns developments since last #RCGPCouncil, including our recent letter to @sajidjavid covered in @guardian https://t.co/7pXFD89EfN
#RCGPCouncil now hearing updates from @RCGPWales, @RCGPScotland and @rcgp_ni
#RCGPCouncil member: Retention isn't improved by appraisal. There is evidence that appraisal and revalidation are contributing to the problem
#RCGPCouncil member: We could look at restricted licences for GPs approaching retirement to keep them in the workforce longer. Should we think the unthinkable, e.g. restricted list sizes?
#RCGPCouncil member: The real issue is  workload. It's out of control. We're looking at downstream solutions. We need a renaissance of general practice.
#RCGPCouncil member: Retention scheme in our area is discretionary and hard to get onto.
#RCGPCouncil member: I love being a partner but if someone offered to take that away and let me just see patients, I might bite their hand off. 5 clinical sessions should be what a full-time GP does.
#RCGPCouncil member: North of Scotland has chronic retention problems despite the schemes we have in place. We should be asking not just why GPs leave but why they stay.
#RCGPCouncil member: Workplace culture is an issue, e.g. divide between partners and salaried GPs. We need to be kind to each other.

#RCGPCouncil member: There is no accurate GP workforce data in England so we need to be slightly careful. Accurate data will enable us to take granular view. Lack of maternity cover/support is a big problem.
#RCGPCouncil member: IMGs have no family support & young children so we could think about how we support this group.
#RCGPCouncil member: Returners are a failure of retention. 10% leave because of disability, illness or ill health. We need to support these doctors to stay in work.

#RCGPCouncil member: retention schemes are supporting struggling docs but not addressing the underlying problem. RCGP and BMA should be defining what is a safe workload. Also returner scheme too difficult to access.
#RCGPCouncil member: Everyone is at risk of walking away because of unmanageable workload. We need to stop GPs burning out in the first place. How do we regain the joy of general practice?
#RCGPCouncil member: To solve the retention problem, we need to make the daytime job doable.
#RCGPCouncil member: Loss of GPs is a major patient safety issue. Exhausted doctors are likely to make mistakes.

#RCGPCouncil now turns its attention to a policy paper on GP retention. How do we stop GPs quitting the profession? Which groups of GPs are leaving & why? How are existing retention schemes working & how can they be improved?
#RCGPCouncil now taking a break for lunch.
#RCGPCouncil member: ‚ÄòIf a doctor does not care about health inequalities, how can they even be a doctor?‚Äô to quote Chris Whitty,

#RCGPCouncil member: The evidence base for social prescribing is still limited. Why should you rely on a social prescriber to get your benefits? The system needs to change. We need to challenge Governments to address these problems upstream.
#RCGPCouncil member: We could look at expanding the number of public health rotations for trainees.
#RCGPCouncil member: At which level in the system do we perform this role? It should be at place level - not practice or PCN level.
#RCGPCouncil member: we will struggle to undertake the role of community health improvement if we don't tackle the workload problem first.
#RCGPCouncil member: We can't reduce health inequalities but we can 'mitigate'.
#RCGPCouncil member: It's not just about data - we need to triangulate with lived experience.
#RCGPCouncil member: Is this a priority for general practice? Or are others better placed to tackle poverty?

#RCGPCouncil member: The most important thing we can do is to bring the general practice and public health functions together. However we also need to mention the climate crisis as one of the wider social determinants of health.
#RCGPCouncil member: We need high quality data and coding to ensure that we understand our patient populations.
#RCGPCouncil member: We thought PCNs would be doing exactly this but DES has taken us in a different direction.
#RCGPCouncil member: We are 'sticking plaster GPs' treating symptoms. Wouldn't it be better to be preventing these problems developing in the first place?

#RCGPCouncil member: General practice played a community health engagement role during the pandemic. We should prioritise preventative medicine but need additional funding to support practices to do this
#RCGPCouncil member: The paper does not say that all GPs must play a public health role but it's a function for local systems.
#RCGPCouncil member: We are returning to the historical role of GP as community leader.
#RCGPCouncil member: the move to population health management is helpful and a vital area of work for the College. But don't underestimate the workload challenge

#RCGPCouncil now discussing a paper on the role of general practice in community health improvement. Is this a role for GPs? Where is this done well? What tools, skills & resources do GPs needs to improve the health of communities?
#RCGPCouncil votes to continue work in this area
#RCGPCouncil member: query around the timing of this discussion: why now?

#RCGPCouncil member: exploration of new role should consider potential unintended consequences, with learning from when new roles have been introduced previously. Will need to agree an evidence framework.

#RCGPCouncil member: in army and navy always employed 'general duty medical officers' - in effect working as GPs - gaining lots of experience in primary healthcare with great benefit. Many who don't want to be GP at start of career, change mind after working as GDMO
#RCGPCouncil member: role of College is to maintain standards, how can we if we're not part of the conversation? 30% of medical doctors in UK are SAS doctors - this should be an opportunity
#RCGPCouncil member: important for RCGP to be an active stakeholder in any discussions about Primary Care Doctor role
#RCGPCouncil member: need to be clear re: what the purpose of introducing a non-GP doctor role in general practice would be, and whether this would be best way to achieve it

#RCGPCouncil member: trainees want to know College is engaged in this debate and not leaving it to other organisations to make decisions that affect the profession on its behalf. We should also not always see a supervision role as a burden despite workload pressures.

#RCGPCouncil member: inverse care law very much alive, CMO in England has identified severe GP workforce issues in coastal towns and dire impact on patients - Primary Care Doctor role could be part of solution
#RCGPCouncil member: concerns around supervision burden and decision-making support Primary Care Doctors may need and how this would impact on GP workload
#RCGPCouncil member: need to explore idea of doctors who are specialists in other areas of medicine who want to switch to general practice and routes for them to do this
#RCGPCouncil member: important that focus on exploring concept of non-GP doctor doesn't detract from support of GPs. Need to explore reasons people have difficulty achieving CCT
#RCGPCouncil member: want to understand the evidence, the data, what is good, what is bad re: intro of non-GP doctor role, so would welcome College exploring concept further

#RCGPCouncil member: patients want to be cared for by a competent person - if the different competencies of GPs/non-GP doctors are explained to them, they would accept a new role, especially as could improve access

#RCGPCouncil member: opportunity for the College to contribute to the development of a Primary Care Doctor role. Similar role has existed in secondary care for years with benefit & could be made to work in general practice. Would help attract more to choose PC and ease workload
#RCGPCouncil member: RCGP should explore this space further, but thinking should be modeled on different career stages and type: 'new in practice', salaried, partners, and late career/retired
#RCGPCouncil member: this group of doctors, who have not specialised for whatever reason, must not be forgotten
#RCGPCouncil member: concerns around non-GP grade of doctor as undermines achievements of newly qualified GPs achieving MRCGP and would be confusing for patients
#RCGPCouncil member: currently only way to work in NHS if you are a doctor who hasn't specialised is in hospitals. Primary Care Doctor role would allow them to work in general practice

#RCGPCouncil member: this is not about lowering standard of MRCGP exam or patient care, but opening up the options for doctors who have already been invested in. Lots of thinking to do in this space before solid options are discussed
#RCGPCouncil member: support for College to explore concept further - can see pros and cons - but concern around where the role of Primary Care Doctor would sit

#RCGPCouncil member: there are implications around GP training, the GP exam etc. There would be a way to make the concept work, and all work together, perhaps a role of 'Community clinician' as opposed to 'PC doctor' might allow for greater inclusion of other roles?

#RCGPCouncil member: concerns around the creation of a two-tier (GP/non-GP) system of doctors in general practice. What would the role of Primary Care Doctor be? How would they be perceived by patients? Would there be unintended consequences on GP workload re: supervision?
For the purposes of the paper, the non-GP doctor is referred to as 'Primary Care Doctor' #RCGPCouncil
First up, #RCGPCouncil is asked to consider the implications of widening the primary care workforce to accommodate a non-GP grade of doctor, and whether RCGP should explore the concept further
Policy paper discussions about to commence at #RCGPCouncil. A reminder: comments are from individual Council members and not necessarily reflective of RCGP policy
#RCGPCouncil takes a brief break
#RCGPCouncil member says: we need help from NHS leaders to create a unified data set for general practice, not to be used to beat the profession with but to assist quality improvement

A number of #RCGPCouncil members raise issue of long Covid and the impact it is having on GPs, some of whom are unable to work because of the condition with implications for individuals and wider workforce

#RCGPCouncil member says: we have to continue emphasising how good it is to be a GP despite the intense pressures facing the profession. This week HEE announced 100% fill rate in GP training places: 4000 this year

#RCGPCouncil member raises issue around Covid-19 vaccination as a condition of employment in the NHS. Read our latest statement and submission to the consultation on this issue here: https://t.co/voeZ18Qojj
#RCGPCouncil member says: College's Research and Surveillance Centre will be 55 years old next year. Find out more: https://t.co/rGqn6iNLO4
#RCGPCouncil now hearing an update on the College's work over the last two months from Chief Operating Officer, Valerie Vaughan-Dick
#RCGPCouncil takes a moment to remember those colleagues who have passed since our last Council meeting
The RCGP President is the constitutional head of the College. It is the Chair of Council who sets the strategic direction and policy, currently @MartinRCGP #RCGPCouncil
.@MartinRCGP welcomes newly elected #RCGPCouncil members, new @RCGPWales Chair @ChristmasRowena, new Chairs of AiT and First 5 Committees, new Faculty representatives, and new Council observers
.@MartinRCGP confirms the RCGP Officer team for 2021/22, welcoming @docmagsy as new Vice Chair for Professional Development and @michael_mul1 in his new role as Hon Sec #RCGPCouncil
New College President @ClareGerada makes some opening remarks to kick off #RCGPCouncil and reappoints @MartinRCGP as Chair of Council, who takes his seat to start proceedings
#RCGPCouncil will commence at 9 o'clock

Have you caught up with our latest Essential Knowledge Update podcast episode yet? Listen to @drtomround talk to GP and #osteoporosis expert Dr David Stephens about how to navigate different guidelines and provide the best care for your patient: https://t.co/VvKh2ForoO

Read our 10-minute consultation feature in the latest #GPFrontline College magazine - In this issue we speak to #Nottinghamshire GP @drcartersingh and find out why he thinks it's important to be a College member  https://t.co/0MUw22NI6b

Amendments to the #HealthAndCareBill will be debated by MPs next week. Find out more about an amendment on workforce planning that the College, @RCPhysicians  and over 60 organisations have tabled, with the support of nearly 40 MPs including  @Jeremy_Hunt & @JonAshworth https://t.co/krAVD51U6P

Also in Our GP Lives series, Dr Gerda Pohl discusses two decades improving medical care in remote communities. Read about her striking experiences in the latest #GPFrontline magazine https://t.co/b3JBnXhzv1

Dr Mikhail Varshavski, @RealDoctorMike to his millions of followers, is using social media to cut through fake news - Find out how in our GP Lives series in the latest #GPFrontline College magazine https://t.co/Hgd54E8G8r

.@MartinRCGP - there‚Äôs a saying ‚Äòbe optimistic, it feels better‚Äô. General practice has been through dark times in the past, and we bounce back, because GP is vital in keeping our health service sustainable

.@NikkiKF - I absolutely believe the future is bright for general practice, We have to, we couldn‚Äôt do the jobs we‚Äôre doing if we didn‚Äôt believe in general practice, it‚Äôs a fundamental part of our society

Q - how can you persuade GPs thinking of leaving to stay in the profession? @draartibansal - there is something precious about having a health service that is focussed on what patients need. It‚Äôs an amazing job and NHS, it‚Äôs just underfunded.

.@MartinRCGP - we know that a ‚Äòthree day week‚Äô in general practice means working a 40 hour week. Forcing people to work more days when they are already under intense pressure is a complete nonsense. We‚Äôre in a safety critical profession

Q: how do we change the narrative around part time GPs? @BecksFisher - it‚Äôs ridiculous and probably based in misogyny, the narrative needs to change, we need to do better at making clear how hard we‚Äôre working and gathering data to demonstrate that
.@MartinRCGP - it‚Äôs important for the College to be really supportive of the sustainability and planetary health agenda. It can‚Äôt be ‚Äòjust something else‚Äô to think about
.@NikkiKF - it‚Äôs about being more aware of our surroundings, looking at prescribing and wastage, looking at our estates. But the small steps are just as important as the big ones

.@draartibansal - we need to get to net zero and we need to do it now. It‚Äôs a misconception that this is a long term thing. I won‚Äôt talk about what practices should do, we need to see green plans at a system level

Q: three things practices can do to be more green? @draartibansal - sustainable healthcare is the same as good person centred care. The main thing we can do is focus on prevention, we should invest in things that reduce need for healthcare
.@NikkiKF we need to build the workforce of AHPs in general practice, but we also have to recruit more GPs and retain them
Q: are AHPs a solution to pressures or a distraction? @BecksFisher - part of a solution, but partly a distraction, however many AHPs we have in general practice, we still need thousands more GPs
.@draartibansal - people need to see their GP wherever they live. The focus on convenience medicine is very London-centric, and the drive for it is driven by people who are relatively well
Q: is political decision making too London/Southeast-centric? @NikkiKF  - we try to make our team as diverse as possible, and we really try to move around the country speaking to GPs
.@MartinRCGP - people fascinate me more than diseases, that is the attraction of general practice for me. Delivering cradle to grave care is a huge privilege

.@draartibansal - I was asked ‚Äòdo you really want to listen to patients talk to you about their cat?‚Äô My answer was ‚Äòyes!‚Äô Things change, we‚Äôre in a difficult spot, but if we invest in GP the job will become brilliant again

.@BecksFisher - med students are programmed to want to be consultants when they start medical school‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt know at the time but choosing GP was the best decision. I find the NextGen GP network really inspiring. It‚Äôs hard but doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not the best career

Q: Any advice for GPs starting out with all the pressures? @NikkiKF - whether or not we‚Äôd had a pandemic, things would be really hard in general practice, but being in practice is the highlight of my week and we should be really proud of what we do in our communities

.@draartibansal - there‚Äôs a fundamental misunderstanding about what general practice does, and we need to be clear about it. We deal with complex physical and mental health needs, we deal with risk, we deal with building trust with patients
.@MartinRCGP - we need to work with our patients to ensure the balance is right between face to face and remote consultations. One in six consultations at the moment are being delivered in person
.@NikkiKF - yesterday‚Äôs document talks about offering face to face appointments when there is a clinical need, but there are other factors to consider too, including preference
.@MartinRCGP my main concern about the announcement is that the ‚Äòbottom‚Äô 20% of practices, the ones that most need support, will be vilified, not supported

.@NikkiKF - there is no silver bullet. What we need to do is stay close to our patients on this. It was absolutely right to intro zero tolerance on abuse of GPs/staff. Ultimately it‚Äôs hybrid & flex model so GPs can do what they need to do clinically in best interests of patients
.@draartibansal - there was an element of me that thought this is confused and laughable. The Government is going down populist root

How does panel respond to the latest Government announcement on general practice? @BecksFisher - will this fix the overall struggle we face in general practice? No. What we need wasn‚Äôt on offer yesterday - we need comprehensive workforce plan & SoS to have major change of heart

.@CMO_England receives a standing ovation at the #RCGPAC as the day‚Äôs first session ends

‚ÄúI wish I could claim everything would be great by Christmas, but I sadly can‚Äôt. But we are in a much much better place, and that is largely down to GPs and their teams. Thank you for your tremendous work.‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC
‚ÄúNever worry about criticism you wouldn‚Äôt take advice from‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

‚ÄúI spend a lot of time looking at what‚Äôs done differently in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland and learning from it. The support from CMOs and Deputy CMOs in devolved nations has been very helpful.‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

‚ÄúThe correct dialogue to get us to the right place on face to face consultations is between the GP and their doctor, and we need to get to a point where the median person thinks there is a fair balance‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

‚ÄúSome pandemics have similarities, but others are completely different. There are lessons to be learned from each pandemic, but there will always be variation in pandemics and how we need to deal with them‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

‚ÄúWe need to have a national think about health inequalities. My annual report focussed on coastal towns, but there are other sets of areas that have shared problems and we need to identify them and work out what to do to reduce health inequalities‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

‚ÄúScience in a new pandemic will inevitably move on. I‚Äôm always very clear that I am giving advice based on what we know now. There will always be a lot of uncertainty with a new virus.‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

‚ÄúMy job as @CMO_England is to represent medical opinion, and GPs form a huge part of that, and the general public have a huge amount of respect for our professional opinions. Doctors are the most trusted profession and when people say that they mean GPs‚Äù #RCGPAC

‚ÄúThere is a reason I came here. I massively admire everything you have done. It has been massively difficult and the way general practice has risen to the challenge, with the vaccine programme and keeping everything going has been magnificent‚Äù @CMO_England #RCGPAC

3/3 Also not mentioned is that a quarter of GPs are working 50 hours a week or more ‚Äì to put into context, pilots aren‚Äôt allowed to fly more than 32 hrs in 7 days for safety reasons.
Therefore, GPs nominally working part time are in fact working full time.

2/2 What isn‚Äôt mentioned is that according to the report the article is based on an average 6-session GP works a 40 hr week. A session is 4hr10, so six sessions should = 25 hr. In the model contract, full time is 9 sessions or 37.5 hours.

Severe workload and workforce pressures mean working ‚Äòpart time‚Äô in general practice is the equivalent of working full-time or more. Read the College‚Äôs latest rebuttal to today‚Äôs article in @theTelegraph about GP working hours. @MartinRCGP https://t.co/TCXKgCPYhz 1/2

8- Government and national NHS leaders need to recognise the strain the NHS is under and help us to explain this to the public and take action.
7-Doctors, nurses, pharmacists and others across primary and secondary care have worked to their limits over the last 18 months. Now they face what is likely to be an incredibly difficult winter.
6- But there are other, longer-term causes too ‚Äì most importantly a legacy of poor workforce planning and successive governments failing to invest appropriately in general practice.

5- We understand that patients are frustrated when they find it difficult to access care and healthcare professionals share these frustrations. Some reasons for this are a legacy of the pandemic, such as the ongoing need for some infection control measures.

4- The shift towards digitally-enabled care is not unique to general practice: it is also happening in secondary care, for example with increasing use of online tools to provide outpatient consultations or talking therapies.

3- Face to face care will always be an essential part of general practice ‚Äì but good care can also be delivered remotely. It is convenient to patients and can give patients more control over how and when they access services.

2- What isn‚Äôt being acknowledged is the care that is being given in general practice on a daily basis. More than 14.6 million face to face GP surgery appointments were delivered in July - 57% of the total ‚Äì with 45% of appointments taking place on the day they were requested.

Divisive and distorted claims about GP access simply serve to demoralise the very people who are going above and beyond every day to keep the NHS running safely. Read @MartinRCGP and @NHSProviders @Saffron_Policy in @IndyVoices. https://t.co/if13fOJfSc

We‚Äôre at #Lab21 today meeting MPs and health organisations to talk about the pressure on GPs. First up @MartinRCGP speaking at @RCPhysicians @NVTweeting roundtable about how we reduce the NHS backlog.
#RCGPCouncil comes to a close

#RCGPCouncil now hearing updates from Devolved Nation chairs in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Huge amounts of influencing work going on across the UK with huge workload pressures on GP across all nations.
#RCGPCouncil member says it‚Äôs great to see how seriously the College is taking the climate emergency but it would be great to see @rcgp get to net-zero as soon as possible.

#RCGPCouncil now discussing @rcgp work on the climate emergency. The paper explores how best to support GPs reduce their carbon footprint, influencing govt policy and reducing the College‚Äôs own carbon emissions.
#RCGPCouncil says that a ‚Äúone size fits all‚Äù safeguarding training approach is not helpful. Another members says we do not have enough resources underpinning safeguarding work.

#RCGPCouncil member says some GPs struggle to access good safeguarding training as it isn‚Äôt done at medical school level. Work ongoing to develop undergraduate training which should help in years to come.
#RCGPCouncil now debating a safeguarding training paper which calls on @rcgp to work with partners to increase the flexibility of safeguarding training & work to articulate a requirement for GPs.

#RCGPCouncil suggests limiting appraisal to free up GP time and remove further stress and worry from GP. Another member says GP admin is still too much - it‚Äôs important GPs spend time on clinically relevant tasks.
#RCGPCouncil now discussing an item on GP workload. Range of contributions from members about patient empowerment, the misuse of GPDPR impacting on GP time, and over-diagnosis.

#RCGPCouncil member says that we should treat drug misuse like other illnesses. Too often vulnerable people are abandoned to the system without an appropriate advocate. Investing in research is also essential to ensure we‚Äôre using our resources wisely.
#RCGPCouncil says this is very much a political issue ‚Äúthe rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer‚Äù. Problem drug use is fundamentally an issue of poverty.
#RCGPCouncil member says their surgery has had 3 drug related events in the last few weeks; problem drug use is getting worse. This issue is increasingly affecting more and more patients.

#RCGPCouncil member says disinvesting in specialist drug services is a political decision. Another member says the chronic underfunding of public health support both in prison environments and non-prison environments is a huge contributor to problem drug use.

#RCGPCouncil member says that problem drug use goes hand in hand with deprivation. The fragmentation of specialist services has hugely contributed to the ongoing crisis. It‚Äôs essential to reduce the stigma if we‚Äôre to better care for patients.

#RCGPCouncil are now debating a paper on drug-related harms. There is now a record number of drug-related deaths recorded in the UK. This paper calls for an evidence-based approach to explore solutions.
#RCGPCouncil Our Chief Operating Officer is giving an update about the College‚Äôs Equality, Diversity, and Inclusion Plan for the forthcoming year.

 for her time as RCGP President as today is her last #RCGPCouncil meeting
#RCGPCouncil member: there are lots of good news stories and we need to hear more of them. It's a shame the MSM isn't interested in telling them. We should work with patients to tell positive stories

#RCGPCouncil member: the message isn't landing that huge numbers of GP appointments are being delivered face to face, and that there are some benefits to remote consulting/other new ways of working. Narrative needs to change

#RCGPCouncil member: Faculties have a key role in supporting GPs across the country. We need to recognise that general practice is under extreme stress and we need to listen to colleagues and patients to move forward

#RCGPCouncil member: general practice is becoming a punchbag for the media, but the reports don't tally with the majority of what we're seeing on the ground with patients satisfied with the GP service they are getting

#RCGPCouncil member: GPs are facing trial by media, it is turning patients against the profession and this is manifesting in increasing reports of abuse towards general practice staff, including violence

#RCGPCouncil member suggests a return to personal patient lists may help strengthen those links between patients and clinicians
#RCGPCouncil member says that current pressures in general practice limit delivery of relationship-based care
#RCGPCouncil member says relationship-based care makes general practice more attractive, which may help with workforce pressures.
#RCGPCouncil member suggests papers around relationship-based care, remote care and the MDT should be linked, to reflect the changing nature of general practice.
#RCGPCouncil member says its important to "tell a story" about the value of relationship-based care for patients and clinicians
#RCGPCouncil member notes that relationship based care isn't limited to in-hours general practice. You can build a relationship in a ten minute appointment in other settings such as out-of-hours.
#RCGPCouncil member says "relationship-based care starts at the front desk". All practice staff need to be trained to provide that caring relationship.
#RCGPCouncil member notes that there is an evidence base showing continuity and relationship can improve outcomes.
#RCGPCouncil member says principles of relationship-based care can be codesigned with patients
#RCGPCouncil member notes that longer consultations would give more space for patients and clinicians to build relationships
#RCGPCouncil member says interoperability of systems are important to enable clinicians to have informed consultations with patients
#RCGPCouncil member says that we need research on the benefits and disbenefits of changes in working models. GPs are evidence-based practitioners.
#RCGPCouncil member says that relationship-based care is vital to patient outcomes "if the patients don't trust you, they won't take your advice"
#RCGPCouncil member says relationship-based care is the foundation of GP practice, and must be placed at the heart of training & professional practice,
@MartinRCGP #RCGPCouncil member says "relationship based care is about countinuity, but also coproduction"

@MartinRCGP #RCGPcouncil. This discussion will build on our new paper "The power of relationships: what is relationship-based care and why is it important?", which we launched yesterday.

https://t.co/PPz6glSyNU
#RCGPcouncil now moving on to discuss "Reinvigorating Relationship Based Care", a particular priority for @MartinRCGP as Chair.

.@GaryHowsam wraps up by thanking #RCGPcouncil for another rich discussion covering inequalities, access, planetary health, workload and demand, co-production with patients, and the importance of clear definitions.
#RCGPcouncil member says a lack of face to face experience can be challenging for associates in training
#RCGPcouncil member notes the wide variety of different views and experiences amongst council shared in the discussion so far
#RCGPcouncil members discuss a future mixed economy with different modes to meet different needs
#RCGPcouncil member highlights the access benefits of remote consulting for those who struggle to get to the practice, as well as the need for training to support patients using digital methods
#RCGPcouncil member says improvements in interoperability and sharing of records are crucial
#RCGPcouncil member says their experience of positive remote consultations is often based on relationships built previously face to face
#RCGPcouncil member notes the benefits of remote consulting in terms of reduced travel, carbon emissions and air pollution
"Patients, patients, patients" - #RCGPcouncil member highlights the importance of consulting and involving patients in considering the design of remote and face to face services
#RCGPcouncil members note that digital triage can worsen health inequalities but also that remote consultations can improve access for some
#RCGPcouncil member reports experiences of severe demand and workload challenges posed by the availability of services like e-consult
#RCGPcouncil members highlight the need for further research and evidence on what works and the longer term impacts of new ways of working
#RCGPcouncil members recognise that many clinicians and patients like meeting face to face but also encourage us to consider when face to face appointments are needed and when not
#RCGPcouncil member says training in communication skills using new modes is needed to support effective remote consulting
#RCGPcouncil member notes that their experience is that remote consultations are predominantly conducted by phone rather than video call
#RCGPcouncil member also highlights the challenges around digital literacy and inequality as well as the impact of remote consulting on relationships
#RCGPcouncil member emphasises the need for investment in IT infrastructure to support remote consulting

#RCGPcouncil back from lunch and now discussing a policy paper on remote consultations and patient 'triage', introduced by @GaryHowsam. What are the advantages, risks, access challenges and policy enablers?

Read our report here: https://t.co/7SBgAJuqul

#RCGPcouncil discussion on the MDT is summarised by @michael_mul1. He thanks Council members for the quality of debate & says it‚Äôs crucial we help colleagues and patients understand the role of the MDT team.

A big theme was training & supervision - how do we train our trainers?

#RCGPcouncil member says the role of the GP is changing and evolving and wonders whether the @rcgp should revolve with it: Should we reset and rebrand to be a Royal College of Primary Care consultants?
#RCGPcouncil member says MDT working has now become established in primary care but if the @rcgp is to remain relevant it must own the debate around the future of multi disciplinary team working.

#RCGPcouncil says it‚Äôs crucial we communicate what the MDT offers but more important we communicate what the GP can offer. We must not lose sight of core general practice & workload levels are currently completely unsustainable.

#RCGPcouncil member asks what @rcgp can do to effectively explain the role of the MDT to patients? How do MDT members work with voluntary and community networks? Are there examples of best practice that can be shared?

#RCGPcouncil member says our profession has become unrecognisable from decades ago & it‚Äôs positive that the MDT is now embedded in general practice. However, GPs must be supported & resourced to manage MDT teams; the work cannot be soaked up with no additional resource.

#RCGPcouncil member says that practice nurses and physician associates must get more support and development. It‚Äôs essential that members of the MDT are properly supported if patients are to receive the level of care they deserve.

#RCGPcouncil member says that leadership training must be available to all and not just a select few. There must be additional resource for the considerable time GPs spend managing a multi disciplinary team.

#RCGPcouncil member talks about the importance of population health and asks how we make it as attractive as possible to work in an MDT setting? Suggestion to build on the success of practice nurses and focus on recruitment.
#RCGPcouncil member says support, supervision and oversight from GPs is crucial for the successful integration of the multi-disciplinary team. Regulation of physician associates must be sped up.
#RCGPcouncil member says GPs want to continue doing everything but GPs should not be managing complex co/morbidity alone. GPs cannot do it all and must look for support from the MDT.

#RCGPcouncil now debating a policy paper on the multi-disciplinary team introduced by @michael_mul1. What additional barriers remain to the successful recruitment and integration of the MDT within general practice?

#RCGPCouncil draws to a close. Next meeting: 26 June.
#RCGPCouncil moving into its final stages with a number of formal information items
#RCGPCouncil member: Faculties are central to delivering College support and services at a local level - they are a hub for enthusiasts to come together
#RCGPCouncil member: Faculties have the opportunity to lead the way at a local level on issues such as sustainability - important impact statements are not just seen as tick box exercises
#RCGPCouncil member: key that Faculties don't lose their individuality; ability to tailor events to local members etc
#RCGPCouncil member: important not to follow a one-size-fits-all approach to all Faculties, particularly regarding CPD
#RCGPCouncil member: Faculties have a huge role to play at amplifying the voice of general practice at a local level, including in the media and to local decision makers
#RCGPCouncil is now discussing the role of RCGP Faculties
An official statement from the RCGP on the outcome of this discussion will follow.

#RCGPCouncil member: Covid19 has shone a light on the importance of medical research, including research in primary care. A number of RCGP research awards, inc Research Paper of the Year, now open: https://t.co/CL1k2Ini3C
#RCGPCouncil member: College's work in demystifying genetics for GPs has been really useful - more work along these lines would be helpful

#RCGPCouncil member: there has been an awesome response from practices with almost 2,000 signing up - many over the course of the pandemic - to the College's Research and Surveillance Centre. More info here: https://t.co/rGqn6iNLO4
Next topic for discussion at #RCGPCouncil is an update on the College's work on research and innovation
#RCGPCouncil member: post-Covid is the time to make a difference, and Government can fund changes appropriately if they want to - we have seen the importance of the NHS over the last year
#RCGPCouncil member: questions the timing of the NHS white paper in the middle of the Covid-19 pandemic when most attention is elsewhere, and the shift in power from NHS England to DHSC
#RCGPCouncil member: the lead for ICSs will be a representative from an acute trust, whereas CCGs have been led by GPs - as CCGs will be subsumed into ISCs, the GP voice is likely to be diminished
#RCGPCouncil member: important that members of the wider practice team also have a voice in discussions around integrating care

#RCGPCouncil member: integrated care is a no-brainer, silos don't work, but we need to re-design systems in ways that work best for patients - it shouldn't be framed as integrating to alleviate pressure on secondary care
#RCGPCouncil member: with a transfer of care comes a transfer of risk, so it looks like more risk is heading to general practice when GPs already hold huge amounts of risk
#RCGPCouncil member: primary care is equal to and independent from secondary care - it must not be allowed to become or be seen as subservient to secondary care with initiatives to integrate
#RCGPCouncil member: important that we don't lose the clinical expertise that we've had with GPs being involved in CCGs

#RCGPCouncil member: integrated care is not just primary and secondary care, it's community care too. It's important that the GP voice is seen as an equal partner in any conversations on integrated care
#RCGPCouncil member: any initiatives to integrate NHS systems need to be implemented with deprivation in mind, and with sufficient funding and resources not to widen health inequalities
#RCGPCouncil member: some things in the NHS white paper could mean a very different future for general practice, depending on how they are interpreted, which is worrying
#RCGPCouncil now discussing a paper on integrated care, including the NHS white paper on integration and innovation

#RCGPCouncil member: unfortunately inspections are often seen as a tick-box exercise with those that are 'inspection-savvy' at an advantage. Any review needs to be with an aim to learn not blame, w/o predetermined ideas about what outcome will be
#RCGPCouncil member: from a patient perspective, it is essential that general practice has a diverse workforce, and that any barriers to achieving this are broken down
#RCGPCouncil member: should be easy for GPs to ask for help and support if they need it, and not be made to feel like they are bad doctors

#RCGPCouncil member: important to understand the impact that poor CQC ratings can have on the health and wellbeing of GPs and other practice staff - it can be devastating, which is not conducive to delivering high quality patient care
#RCGPCouncil member: risk is that data shows a correlation but isn't detailed enough to establish causation. Must take a collaborative approach to any review that doesn't seek to establish blame
#RCGPCouncil member: important that CQC inspectors are representative of the workforce they are inspecting, and undergo appropriate cultural awareness training

#RCGPCouncil member: my suspicion is that there is at best a deprivation marker linked to CQC rating, and at worst one linked to ethnicity. CQC inspection methodology needs to take into account deprivation of the area/demographics of the population
#RCGPCouncil member: at some point we need to think about whether there is evidence that inspections improve quality
#RCGPCouncil member: hugely thankful to all of the GPs who have come to the UK from overseas to deliver patient care over the last 50 years, many of whom are still practising

#RCGPCouncil member: poor CQC inspection results often come with a stigma, which makes it hard to improve, particularly without sufficient funding/support. Inspectors should have understanding of local area/situation of the practices they inspect

#RCGPCouncil member: would be good to see a review of all GP practices rated 'requires improvement' or 'inadequate' so any trends can be examined, and that all protected characteristics taken into account
#RCGPCouncil member: GPs and our teams are all in favour of providing a high standard of patient care - vital that all are treated in an equitable way
#RCGPCouncil member: evidence from Deep End practices shows those with most deprived communities have less access to funding/resources, and needs to feed into any review

(2/2) If association is found, for the reasons to be explained with a view to tackling evidence of less favourable treatment of BAME GPs and their practices, thereby improving transparency of processes and building confidence in CQC #RCGPCouncil

3 - to commission independent review of inspections of GP practices rated 'requires improvement' or 'inadequate' over past 5 yrs, inc those that have closed, to assess if there is association between outcome of inspections and ethnicity/country of qualification (1/2) #RCGPCouncil
2 - to work with RCGP to discuss how availability and transparency of such info can be improved and to ensure BAME GPs' experiences of being regulated by CQC are heard #RCGPCouncil

1 - to share details of previous/ongoing/planned studies and data to explore whether there is evidence of conduct/outcomes of inspections being affected by ethnicity/country of qualification of practising GPs #RCGPCouncil

#RCGPCouncil resumes. First discussion on a motion to Council calling on the CQC for a series of measures to look at the impact of its inspections on GPs from Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities
#RCGPCouncil breaks for lunch
#RCGPCouncil now hearing updates from across the UK from Devolved Council Chairs from @RCGPScotland @RCGPWales and @rcgp_ni

#RCGPCouncil member: at this stage in the pandemic, is it an opportunity to refresh the College's #FutureGP workforce roadmap, with particular emphasis on harnessing the potential of skillsets within PCNs?

#RCGPCouncil member: to encourage people to take the Covid19 vaccine if they are hesitant, particularly those in Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities, we need to understand the reasons why they are hesitant and address them
#RCGPCouncil member: bureaucracy during the pandemic, particularly in terms of allowing GPs to return to practice, has got worse not better as resources/support has been diverted elsewhere
#RCGPCouncil member: the CVP is an opportunity for GPs and our teams to reach out to our communities, and try to increase uptake amongst all patient groups

#RCGPCouncil member: there is confusion amongst patients with changing advice not to call the GP to make an appointment for vaccination, and then to proactively make an appointment. We need simple, clear communications to patients

#RCGPCouncil member: on calls for public health campaigns to increase vaccine uptake amongst Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities, important to involve media outlets that target BAME communities

#RCGPCouncil member: there is going to be an increasing need to make it easier for retired GPs to return to practice in some capacity - not necessarily just for vaccination programme - so process to return to performers list should be assessed
#RCGPCouncil member: endorses the exceptional leadership that has been shown by general practice throughout the pandemic, both at a national and local level
#RCGPCouncil has resumed. Next discussion is on the College's response to the #Covid19 pandemic
#RCGPCouncil member: the inadequacy of the 10 minute consultation, particularly for patients with complex needs, should be reflected in future examination
#RCGPCouncil member: GPs do a lot of work outside of the clinical consultation - developing an exam might be a good opportunity to reflect this

#RCGPCouncil member: important to consider different ways of working during #Covid19 - total triage/remote consulting - in development of exam, but also need to consider general practice in the future, not just during pandemic

#RCGPCouncil member: whilst acknowledging necessity of examination, trainee wellbeing should be taken into account - learning and exposure to frontline GP should not be overshadowed by preparation for exam
#RCGPCouncil member: changing an exam process must be carefully considered. One thing that should be considered is trainees being able to take exams locally

#RCGPCouncil member: key to development of an exam will be to ensure standards of patient care are maintained; also that it should reflect diversity of patients, their circumstances and conditions they may have
#RCGPCouncil is asked for its support to establish an exam development group

#RCGPCouncil member: the RCA was developed as a replacement for the CSA in 12-weeks as a result of the #Covid19 pandemic. It has received both positive feedback and has raised challenges for trainees and examiners which all needs to be taken into account moving forward

#RCGPCouncil hearing an update from Chief Operating Officer Valerie Vaughan-Dick on work of the College since September Council: focus has been on supporting members through the pandemic/CVP, increasingly looking forward to work to achieve objectives of strategic plan
#RCGPCouncil pays respects to those Members and Fellows who have sadly died since the last meeting in September
New #RCGPCouncil Members being welcomed, including new @RCGPScotland joint Chairs, David Shackles and Chris Williams
Thanks to the College's Chief Examiner MeiLing Denney whose term comes to end in May #RCGPCouncil

It just remains to thank all the speakers and contributors, our sponsors and panel chairs (including our brilliant officer team), @michael_mul1 (Chair of the Conference Committee), the staff who've made the whole event run smoothly and all our delegates. #rcgpfa

.@AmandaCHoweRCGP now touches on some highlights of the conference. 

Over the last two days, >1000 delegates have shared ideas and learning. More than 250 posters have been exhibited across 12 categories. We've honed clinical practice and explored some of big issues.

What's one resource which we could share to improve practice to address inequalities

@D_R_Williams1 highlights Blindspot by Mahzarin Banaji, plus some of the papers included in the presentation (do rewatch!)
It may be that "race" is more useful as a term to capture different social experiences, rather than a biological variable. It's important to define your terms. #rcgpfa

.@AmandaCHoweRCGP finds time for a question about the language used to describe race or ethnicity.

@D_R_Williams1 agrees this is a very complex area, but a good starting point is to use the terms the specific populations prefer.

A fantastically rich talk from @D_R_Williams1, with plenty for us to mull over. 

The good news is that conference delegates can re-watch the session on demand for 6 months! #rcgpfa
@DrBenJacksn Glad to hear it. We're optimistic that we will be able to meet face-to-face in Liverpool in October! https://t.co/fJuaF1Ejvn
3) Connect patients with non-medical services to improve health (social prescribing). #rcgpfa
2) ensure the workforce looks like the population at all levels - this is valuable for both the patient-clinician relationship, and for awareness of different medical needs. #rcgpfa
1) Reduce differences in the quality of care provided to different ethnic groups, by taking on implicit biases (@D_R_Williams1 notes that data on this is lacking in the UK). #rcgpfa
So what should be done about this?
.@D_R_Williams1 argues that these systemic disadvantages and bad environmental conditions are taking a physiological toll, what you might call "premature aging". #rcgpfa
"Low economic status means that, though everyone is going through the same storm of the pandemic, not everyone is in the same size of boat."  #rcgpfa

A 1997 study found that, if residential segregation could be eliminated in the US, gaps in income and high school graduation rates would disappear! 

Residential segregation is less of a factor in the UK, but it is is present.
#rcgpfa

Even after accounting for wealth, education and deprivation, inequities between ethnic groups prevail. @D_R_Williams1 suggests that institutional discrimination (aka structural racism) can help explain these inequities #rcgpfa
@SoniaAdesara @D_R_Williams1 Yes, it will all be available on demand for 6 months for registered delegates.
.@D_R_Williams1 highlights that, alongside these health inequalities, there are similar, persistent inequities in income and wealth.

These inequities aren't limited to #COVID19 or to the USA. 

In the UK, the risk of death in pregnancy is five times higher for black people than white people. #rcgpfa

We start with #COVID19 data from the USA, where @D_R_Williams1 highlights shocking disparities in death rates between different ethnicities. Historically disadvantaged groups are twice as likely to die in this context. #rcgpfa

We've almost come to end of our online conference, "A Fresh Approach to General Practice", but there's just time for one final session: "Social inequities in health: What each of us can do" with @D_R_Williams1. #rcgpfa

We're now breaking into parallel sessions, with topics ranging from diagnosing skin lesions to delivering social prescribing. 

We'll be back for our final plenary, with @AmandaCHoweRCGP & @D_R_Williams1 at 3.25pm. Until then, enjoy the conference. #rcgpfa
And now a strong challenge that we as professionals need to take a more active stance on poverty and social justice, taken up by @Christy_Melam and @BeckyMalby. #rcgpfa
@MartinRCGP emphasises the need to grow GP training capacity, an ongoing priority for the College. #rcgpfa

A question on the ethics of international recruitment

@Prerana_Issar points out (as @markbritnell did yesterday) that global healthcare demand outstrips supply - so we need a collaborative 'learn and return' model. #rcgpfa

@BeckyMalby offers 3 suggestions to work as a whole system. 
1) Digital outpatient appointments 
2) Case reviews with colleagues across the system
3) Multi-professional Schwarz rounds to bear witness to experiences
#rcgpfa

@Prerana_Issar emphasises the support offer available to general practice and staff across the NHS, at https://t.co/EOEJihCxkI, with additional support in development for the post-pandemic recovery.

Preventative care is the most effective care. #rcgpfa

@BeckyMalby says our people need to be honest and ask for help when they need it, rather than maintaining a fa√ßade of heroism. Staff will need space, time & support to cope with what has happened.  #rcgpfa
@Prerana_Issar - the pandemic has shown us that we still have work to do to tackle health inequalities - and that will require the whole NHS working together.

@MartinRCGP notes that it is not always clear what does or doesn't require the skills of a GP. Something which looks, at first sight, to be a simple transactional issue may bring to light something much more significant.
@Christy_Melam suggests that we need to empower communities, and that's where social prescribing can add real value.

Another question, this time on the crisis in children's and young people's mental health.

A real challenge from @BeckyMalby who argues that we need to reach people where they are if we are to deliver truly universal healthcare.

@Christy_Melam notes that people lead complex lives, and can't effectively be supported in silos. 

We need to work with communities to design integrated pathways which meet patient needs and effectively utilise new roles.

@BeckyMalby takes a question on the need for, and timing of NHS reform. 
"The NHS has needed this [reform towards collaboration] for a long time", but PCNs will need support to get through the coming months and years - restructuring mustn't distract from this.
@Prerana_Issar agrees - workload, working environment and managing the post-pandemic backlog of care are the key challenges here.
@MartinRCGP "We're getting great success in turning on the workforce taps into the bath, but the plug is out"
An important question here about GP retention and burnout - one which the College has long been focus on.
@Prerana_Issar "Healthcare is best delivered close to patients by committed staff" who can address any concerns around vaccine hesitancy, using existing relationships.
@MartinRCGP says that general practice's role in the COVID vaccination practice is a real success story, and something we all should celebrate.
Submit and vote for questions in the Q&A tab!
And to be ably chaired by @Steve_Mowle

And we're back for day two of A Fresh Approach to General Practice. Kicking today off with #NHSQuestionTime in just a few minutes, with @MartinRCGP, @Prerana_Issar, @BeckyMalby & @Christy_Melam #rcgpfa
@gregjirving @RCGPAC Great way to make the poster even more engaging!
We'll be moving into concurrent sessions following a short break, but the live tweeting will continue with NHS Question Time tomorrow morning. #rcgpfa
"Work-life balance, meaningful appraisals and line management are key to retaining a motivated workforce."
@markbritnell notes that digital innovation can support perhaps 36% of healthcare activity. But this needs to be clinician led if it is to succeed.

76% of doctors and 79% of nurses in global studies report performing tasks for which they are overqualified. @markbritnell suggests releasing this time to care can help close the workforce gap, when coupled with creating a new cadre of staff.
New models of care can lead to productivity increases of 16% - 20%!
@markbritnell notes that the WHO has recommended countries to increase investment in primary care by 1% of GDP. "Health can drive wealth" he argues.
@markbritnell lays out 10 solutions, from productivity and new models of care to agile learning and motivation. He argues these need to be delivered concurrently.
There will be a shortage of 18 million healthcare workers globally by 2030 - roughly 20% of healthcare capacity.
@markbritnell notes that much discussion of the healthcare workforce is long on analysis, but sadly short on solutions. #rcgpfa
Now joined by @markbritnell, of @KPMG and @TheKingsFund to talk about the global healthcare workforce crisis. #rcgpfa
"there‚Äôs nothing soft about relationships and our interest in relationships isn‚Äôt yearning for a lost and never to be rediscovered past." #rcgpfa

So how can we support clinicians to provide relationship-based care? 

@MartinRCGP suggests "we need to ramp up teaching and training about relationship-based medicine in the specialist training curriculum"

"we know that remote consultations have a role to play in the emerging general practice landscape ‚Äì some patients prefer them, and so do some GPs. But... it‚Äôs much harder to build a relationship with a patient, to establish trust and empathy, through a remote consultation."
"One key practical step is to increase the length of non-triage GP consultations; the traditional 10-minute consultation is a major impediment to relationship based care"

@MartinRCGP asks what that means for general practice? 

"Are relationships sufficiently important that they should be actively promoted and designed into future models of general practice? I think that the evidence-based benefits that I‚Äôve outlined suggest that they should be"
"The evidence tells us that patients want to know that clinicians are keen to engage emotionally" @MartinRCGP #rcgpfa
@MartinRCGP explores what makes up relationship-based care - continuity of care, the therapeutic relationship, empathy and person-centred care

"we‚Äôve long recognised the power of the so-called therapeutic relationship but it seems to me that we haven‚Äôt always been sufficiently explicit about just how important it is... As a consequence many people simply don‚Äôt understand how important relationships are."

@MartinRCGP talks about why reinvigorating relationship-based care is one of the RCGP's priorities: "We all have stories about how the relationships that we build with with our patients are an important part of our effectiveness as clinicians."
"remarkably over 75% of the over 13 million vaccines administered so far in the UK have been delivered by general practice." #rcgpfa

@MartinRCGP opens his conference speech, recognising the importance of feeling valued: "It‚Äôs remarkable how selfless people are when they feel that what they‚Äôre doing, however tough, is valued by others." #rcgpfa

#RCGPCouncil draws to a close
#RCGPCouncil now hearing updates from @rcgp_ni @RCGPWales and @RCGPScotland - lots of work ongoing across the devolved nations to support GPs through the #Covid19 pandemic

#RCGPCouncil member: moonshot programme is the biggest national screening programme in the UK that hasn't been through the national screening committee. We need to be careful here.  More than ever we need more science now, not less
#RCGPCouncil member: important that GP trainee involvement in the #Covid19 vaccine doesn't negatively impact on their training
#RCGPCouncil member: there has been a phenomenal response from practices wanting to support the work of the Research and Surveillance Centre during #Covid19
#RCGPCouncil member: important that #GPisOpen resources are updated for patients if and as things change over the next few months
#RCGPCouncil member: important that as a College we are analysing and where appropriate challenging the research and data around #Covid19 vaccine

#RCGPCouncil member: need clarification from JCVI as to why members of Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities are not specifically included in the #Covid19 vaccine priority list given how they are disproportionately affected by the virus
A reminder - tweets attributed to '#RCGPCouncil member' are the views of an individual member (or Faculty/Committee rep), not necessarily the views of the RCGP
#RCGPCouncil now hearing an update on the work the College has been doing around #Covid19
#RCGPCouncil member: GPs have been working extremely hard throughout the pandemic, but much work as been less visible than elsewhere in the health service
#RCGPCouncil member: need to be practical and prioritise those who really need RBC, often not possible to deliver it to every patient. Some may welcome a transactional approach
#RCGPCouncil member: are we talking about care in the wider sense or just healthcare when we talk about RBC?
#RCGPCouncil member: feedback from trainees and newly qualified GPs report how important the relationship forming part of general practice is, and that it needs to be retained

#RCGPCouncil member: there is evidence lacking around remote consultations - much is historic and doesn't take into account how remote consultations are currently being used. Research needs to be done
#RCGPCouncil member: it's a much more efficient way of delivering general practice to maintain continuity of care, but the funding of general practice needs to make it viable
#RCGPCouncil member: need to think about out of hours care in discussions around RBC

#RCGPCouncil member: #Covid19 had given us a natural experiment around RBC. We need to see a deep dive into how new ways of working during the pandemic have impacted on the care, services and other tasks done in general practice
#RCGPCouncil member: there is a continuum between 'transactional care' and 'RBC' with different patients at different points on the scale

#RCGPCouncil member: shouldn't confuse telephone/video consultations and digital consultations - digital works best when a GP already has a relationship with a patient, but use has risen exponentially since beginning of pandemic and too early to draw conclusions about its use
#RCGPCouncil member: workload was a huge issue pre-pandemic and still is, but much of that workload is not core general practice, and this takes GPs away from being able to deliver RBC
#RCGPCouncil member: RBC is a concept patients have struggled with and we're gaining better understanding - important that any work around invigorating RBC is co-designed with patients
#RCGPCouncil member: GPs had some training in telephone consultations pre-pandemic, other primary care professionals didn't so there is a need for training in this area
#RCGPCouncil member: continuity doesn't always mean with a GP, it is about patients seeing the right healthcare professional at the right time

#RCGPCouncil member: RBC is challenging for individual clinicians, we need to look at it through a multidisciplinary team lens. Sometimes it can be better for a patient to wait longer to see a regular GP - not always possible when prioritising quick access
#RCGPCouncil member: the multi-disciplinary team is key to delivering RBC. We also need to address the tasks in general practice that have become more transactional
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to look at how to maintain RBC with a workforce that is increasingly working less than full time
#RCGPCouncil member: the NHS has made a net-zero promise, but with the exception of inhalers, it isn't clear what the role of primary care will be. Should be linked to RBT work

#RCGPCouncil member: the point of RCT in terms of healthcare needs for patients in the community needs to be made prominent in order to have sway with decision makers. Better access isn't the answer for everyone - continuity is more important for some patients
#RCGPCouncil now discussing relationship-based care - @MartinRCGP's enduring priority for his three-year tenure as Chair
#RCGPCouncil now taking a break
