We had a great time at yesterday's RCGP #Summit - thank you all for joining us. 

Particular thanks to our speakers and to the panel chairs, who did a brilliant job of steering discussions. We couldn't do it without you. #rcgpbf 

See you in February https://t.co/Qp5wf7g6c4!
You can find the programme, and even register for the conference already, here: https://t.co/mPUxcUCMIp.

We'll be meeting again on 11-12 February next year, so we hope you'll be able to join us again then.
 #rcgpbf

But before you "leave", do check out the talks from our Devolved Council Chairs for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland on what the future holds for general practice. You can see the videos via the "Devolved Nations" tab on the left.
#rcgpbf

It just falls to @AmandaCHoweRCGP to close our first ever online RCGP Summit, thanking all our speakers and attendees. 
#rcgpbf

.@careylunan suggests we should work in partnership with other medical royal colleges and the BMA to explore how training opportunities and resources can more effectively address health inequalities. 
#rcgpbf

.@JIDMMatheson begins by touching on the excellent keynote speech given by @MichaelMarmot to last year's RCGP annual conference, and the pioneering work of Julian Tudor Hart. 
#rcgpbf

Our final session of the day focuses on #HealthInequalities, a key problem for general practice, and the wider health of the nation, with @JIDMMatheson, @careylunan @drzanakhan amd @AmandaCHoweRCGP.  
#rcgpbf

Dirk and Steve finish by recommending general practice as the best career around. 

#rcgpbf

Dr @Dirkpilat (RCGP Medical Director, eLearning and Accreditation) emphasises that we all need to look after ourselves, so that we are able to continue to support patients for the long term.
#rcgpbf

Steve emphasises that there's still a lot to learn about COVID-19. 
#rcgpbf

Time for some clinical learning. 
Dr Steve Holmes, one of our excellent Council Members, PCRS Education Lead and a frontline GP in Shepton Mallet, outlines symptoms which COVID patients may experience during recovery. #rcgpbf
Our #AiT chair, @DrAnthonyJames reflects on how the AiT community has grown and become more vibrant over the last year, despite the many challenges to training and exams. #rcgpbf

"I‚Äôm seeing a growing number of GPs starting to explore how they can contribute to the wider health of their communities. I think that‚Äôs exciting and the College is exploring how it can support you."

#rcgpbf

.@MartinRCGP: "we know that the trusting relationship between a patient and a doctor ‚Äì often but not always based on continuity of care - is the most effective intervention that we have at our disposal"
#rcgpbf

.@MartinRCGP: "I‚Äôve learnt so much from conversations with members across the UK as a consequence of the Covid crisis, conversations which make me optimistic about the future of general practice." 
#rcgpbf

"Life for GPs and our teams is going to remain tough. We‚Äôre supporting acute Covid services... delivering a safe flu vaccination programme of unprecedented scale... and of course we‚Äôre delivering business-as-usual acute, long-term and preventative services for patients." #rcgpbf

Martin outlines some of the ways in which the College has responded to COVID-19, from developing a resource hub, webinars and online forum, to supporting research through the RCGP/Oxford Research Surveillance Centre, and helping shape the NHS response. #rcgpbf
.@MartinRCGP: "On behalf of the College, I want to thank you. You are truly remarkable, a credit to your communities, the NHS, and to our specialty... Thank you"

Time now for @MartinRCGP's keynote, his first as RCGP Chair. 
General practice has risen heroically to the challenge of the last year - a challenge of a scale which the NHS has never seen. #rcgpbf
Involving patients in changes in delivery will help them understand how and why changes are happening. Patients get used to changes quickly, and like getting to see the right team-member. #rcgpbf

Questions around the ten minute consultation and growing demand, while dealing with more complexity. Mike agrees its a complex, but giving GPs great control over their time helps, as does sharing work between a team, utilising varied skills. #rcgpbf
Looking at practice data can help practices work out what care they deliver, and build their teams around local needs, to deliver clear benefits. #rcgpbf https://t.co/dWPxDPMBO0

#RCGPCouncil draws to a close
#RCGPCouncil now hearing updates from @rcgp_ni @RCGPWales and @RCGPScotland
3) College has had a number of lobbying wins including successfully pushing for medical school places to be expanded as a result of recent exams chaos... #RCGPCouncil
2) the RCGP has made a submission to the forthcoming Heath Select Committee inquiry into burnout and wellbeing of NHS staff... #RCGPCouncil

.@MartinRCGP making a number of policy announcements to #RCGPCouncil: 1) College lobbying re #TestandTrace for GPs/teams to be prioritised for testing & for GPs to have access to tests for patients w clinical need -but not for general practice to be replacement for central system

#RCGPCouncil member: What GPs can do within scope of what NHS provides is limited, but we can play role in leadership to address HIs and make the case for where funding needs to be directed to make a difference

#RCGPCouncil member: GPs being 'uniquely placed' is overused and absolves better placed professionals from responsibility. Evidence is limited re GPs being able to encourage patients to make long-term lifestyle changes. We need to be careful re making promises we can't deliver
#RCGPCouncil member: as GPs we need to consider moral obligations to patients as well as contractual ones, and we need the resources to be able to do so
#RCGPCouncil member: lots of challenges to addressing health inequalities - digital literacy is one

#RCGPCouncil member: as GPs we are exemplars is multi-tasking, so we do have a chance to help address HIs, we can connect with patients in a way public health professionals can't but we need the funding/resources to help us do this

#RCGPCouncil member: we need to know how to prioritise the post-Covid backlog that we're seeing in general practice. Every crisis is an opportunity to re-base things, work with CCGs to re-route funding where it is needed most, this could help address health inequalities
#RCGPCouncil member: College should look at how to get GPs to commit to working in areas of high-deprivation, and train doctors in these areas and encourage them to stay to care for the population
#RCGPCouncil member: balance data with lived experience from patients and recognising their barriers to why they are living unhealthily (eg inability to afford more healthy food)

#RCGPCouncil member: in 2015 14m people living in poverty. There is an opportunity for GPs - identifying effective interventions is key but to do this we need accurate data from practices to identify those in need

#RCGPCouncil member: GPs have a moral duty to speak out against health inequality and social injustice, but we shouldn't medicalise social inequality - shouldn't be taken away from meeting medical needs of patients, especially with limited workforce capacity

#RCGPCouncil member: health inequalities have always existed, but #COVID19 has held a spotlight to them, and there are opportunities to build back back and try to address them. We want to highlight practical things that can be done to address this historically challenging area.
Next up at #RCGPCouncil, a discussion on health inequalities, "something that has become even more pertinent during the #COVID19 pandemic"
#RCGPCouncil member: climate change and sustainability must be a consideration when entering into commercial partnerships

#RCGPCouncil member: need to see a timeline re when College will act on 10 action points re addressing climate emergency and regular progress reports, particularly on a) integrating planetary health in RCGP curriculum and b) modifying the College's marketing strategy
#RCGPCouncil resumes. First discussion is on sustainability and climate change.
#RCGPCouncil pauses for lunch
#RCGPCouncil member: purely digital or purely face to face learning isn't where we should go, we need a hybrid model to ensure all members can benefit regardless of personal circumstances

#RCGPCouncil member: many successful initiatives start at Faculty level and are essential to provide intimate, local means of education to allow people to learn from each other - idea that all learning goes online is upsetting

#RCGPCouncil member: pandemic has shown the importance of online CPD, but small learning groups at local Faculty level is important and there is opportunity for collaboration - not just for CPD but QI and peer support
#RCGPCouncil member: CPD for the multi-disciplinary team, not just directed at GPs, is appreciated by practice staff and supports GPs/general practice so hope it can continue
Throughout the #COVID19 pandemic, the College's Resource Hub has been free for healthcare professionals and regularly updated: https://t.co/GGh5SQVEvL #RCGPCouncil
#RCGPCouncil now discussing a paper on the College's CPD programme
#RCGPCouncil member: work status should be considered in discussions on EDI e.g. sessional/salaried/partner status of GPs
#RCGPCouncil member: agree with having measurable aspirations but more difficult in some areas of the country than others - should consider proportionate representation
#RCGPCouncil member: when talking about EDI, important to talk about all protected characteristics and intersectionality
#RCGPCouncil member: important to look at EDI issues in terms of what they mean to patients - not just a membership issue
#RCGPCouncil member: use of word 'targets' can have unintended consequences, concept of 'right person right role' is important. Any 'targets' should be representative of College membership
#RCGPCouncil member: encouraged by diversity of candidates in recent #RCGPElection. Need to keep up momentum. Need to reflect on use of the term 'BAME'
#RCGPCouncil member: important EDI plan includes measurable aspirations - would like to see regular reporting to ensure sustained commitment to EDI, and share work that is being done
#RCGPCouncil member: College has made strides re EDI. Important we tackle perceptions of the College that it might not be inclusive for all

#RCGPCouncil member: support the concept of targets re EDI, realise limitations but targets challenge us and help to move forward. Also supports the concept of a freedom to speak up guardian at the RCGP - and more reporting on protected characteristics of membership
A reminder: any posts attributed to an #RCGPCouncil member are not necessarily RCGP policy

#RCGPCouncil draws to a close
#RCGPCouncil now hearing brief updates from @rcgp_ni @RCGPWales and @RCGPScotland on the GP/College response to #COVID19 in each of the devolved nations
#RCGPCouncil now hearing about a short life working group that has been established to look at how the College might change post-COVID
#RCGPCouncil member: opportunity for College to lead on issues with health implications that have been highlighted during COVID eg domestic abuse
#RCGPCouncil member: we should use learnings from working during COVID to reprofessionalise the profession

#RCGPCouncil member: we shouldn't use what's happening now to predicate what will happen in the future. We need evidence re how things like total triage and remote monitoring will work in 'normal time'

#RCGPCouncil member: we could adapt to a different way of working at speed due to relationships GPs have with our patients. General practice stayed open and GPs have worked hard right throughout pandemic. We mustn't lose the relationship-based care GPs are experts at delivering
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to eliminate negative language that is sometimes used to refer to colleagues who want to work differently to the norm. Different is not necessarily lesser.
#RCGPCouncil member: digital solutions welcome, as long as they are effective. We shouldn't forget older tech eg the telephone as well as exploring more high tech solutions

#RCGPCouncil member: doctors do need a way to show continued competence in a way that doesn't take away from being able to deliver patient care - COVID has given us an opportunity to look at what this could look like.

#RCGPCouncil member: every doctor has been affected by COVID and in different ways appraisal is the only outlet we have that gets to every doctor every year, whereby these issues can be identified and appropriate support given
#RCGPCouncil member: is the acceptance of digital consultations just because it is the only game in town? Will this change after COVID? A mixed approach will probably be necessary

#RCGPCouncil member: we need to think about how we only re-introduce stuff that is necessary and should be the work of expert medical generalists. We need to use expertise of overdiagnosis group in determining this.
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to specifically look at the impact of COVID on hard to reach groups, and how we can help address barriers to GP care
#RCGPCouncil member: need to consider out of hours working post-COVID, including important initiatives such as e-prescribing

#RCGPCouncil member: there is a fear that general practice will see an onslaught of workload caused by secondary care - eg patients who have had operations cancelled, not being communicated with - post-COVID
#RCGPCouncil member: some forms of remote monitoring, such as home BP testing, have been an example of a positive coming out of the pandemic

#RCGPCouncil member: in pre-COVID world, an army of pen pushers would not have been able to tick all the bureaucratic boxes that were expected in general practice, and we must not move back to this post-COVID. We need more trust in GPs.
#RCGPCouncil member: important to acknowledge the vulnerability of locums/sessional GPs during COVID

#RCGPCouncil member: need to listen to patients and their perceptions, not just what we think they want - many patients have been responsive to remote consultations with their GP. Workload has been down during pandemic - but demand will be huge during next stages.
#RCGPCouncil member: data from Research Surveillance Centre shows routine consultation numbers was down around 25% at height of COVID, now down around 11% so workload increasing

#RCGPCouncil member: life has moved on from being 'too busy' in many areas; locums have had recruitment issues during COVID. It shouldn't be part of future of GP to do less. We need to look at how we can use changes in ways of working (eg tech) to enhance relationship-based care

#RCGPCouncil member: general practice is a team game, highlighted by COVID, so how can the College reach out to all health professionals who deliver general practice services? Non-GP colleagues have been key in developing rich and helpful resources during pandemic

#RCGPCouncil restarting with a discussion about how the #COVID19 pandemic will shape the future of general practice, looking at: working differently, workload and crossover between general practice and public health
#RCGPCouncil taking a brief break

#RCGPCouncil now hearing an update from College COO Valerie Vaughan-Dick on the work that has been done to support members during #COVID19 eg resource hub, FAQs and member forum. See: https://t.co/qQ9OS0Tms7
#RCGPCouncil taking a moment of silence to remember those members who have died since the last Council meeting, including the 12 GPs who have died as a result of #COVID19
#RCGPCouncil member: should work with stakeholders, for eg the police, to see where College can have most influence
#RCGPCouncil member: a useful piece of work would be to support GPs and practices to call out racism when it is witnessed/experienced

#RCGPCouncil member: not just a case of making a statement, but ensuring members see it. Concrete actions are vital, but a strong statement is important. We need to be comfortable feeling vulnerable and recognising more should be done.

#RCGPCouncil member: there must be a zero tolerance approach to any forms of racism - COVID has shone a light on health inequalities in society. Many issues to address affecting patients and colleagues. Short life working group to develop an action plan would be good start
#RCGPCouncil member: it would be a powerful statement to elect a BAME Council member to College's trustee board
#RCGPCouncil member: the pandemic of systemic racism has been going on far longer that the COVID pandemic
#RCGPCouncil member: 90% GPs who have died from #COVID19 have been from BAME communities. PHE recommendations this week have been a good start but we need to see decisive action
#RCGPCouncil member: important that as a College if any form of racism or sexism is witnessed it will stand up and address it

#RCGPCouncil member: we need a clear action plan to tackle all forms of racism, not just to look like we are doing something. Particular concern around how BAME colleagues have been disproportionately impacted by #COVID19 pandemic

#RCGPCouncil member introduces motion to do more to support BAME colleagues. It asks for a clear, visible statement of support for Black Lives Matter and commitment to tackle structural racism across society.

.@MartinRCGP directing #RCGPCouncil members to the statement he has made in response to the Black Lives Matter movement, and commitment to addressing all inequalities at a College, NHS and societal level. https://t.co/LMKiRyOrPr

ICYMI here‚Äôs @MartinRCGP on @BBCr4today this morning explaining why we need to move away from ‚Äòarbitrary numbers and targets‚Äô to a comprehensive #COVID19 testing plan that tests ‚Äòthe right people at the right time‚Äô https://t.co/F4C7SfhITv (9 min in)

"For most patients, COVID-19 will be a mild illness. If people have symptoms use the NHS 111 tool in the first instance. If patients are ill with other things, general practice is open - albeit remotely in most cases - and they should contact their practice." @MartinRCGP @LBC

"GPs need clear information about who to prioritise for testing, which tests to use, how often we should be testing people, and how will GP records be updated with testing results. These are basic questions, but the answers are key to a good testing plan." @MartinRCGP @LBC

"We all want to see lockdown eased without seeing a second wave in COVID-19 - for that to happen we need a clear testing plan in the community. This is where the virus is being fought now." @MartinRCGP @LBC

"COVID-19 is a strange disease that seems to present in many different ways - some people are getting over it quite quickly, others seem to have it for weeks. It makes it a particular challenge to diagnose." @MartinRCGP @LBC

#RCGPCouncil comes to an end - next meeting 20 June.
#RCGPCouncil now hearing a brief update on the College's CPD strategy
#RCGPCouncil member: sometimes it's a case of not asking what can your College do, but what can you do, and #ClimateChange is one of those things - we need to look outwards, as well as inwards
#RCGPCouncil member: important not to forget steps that the College has already taken to help tackle climate change eg divesting from fossil fuel companies
#RCGPCouncil member: many things College could do - incentives for Faculties to run sustainable events, for example
#RCGPCouncil member: climate change undermines many of the foundations of health - College should work w PHE to produce waiting room posters re what patients can do to help tackle climate change
#RCGPCouncil member: unfortunate that climate emergency was not chosen as a policy and campaigns priority
.@MartinRCGP thanks Climate Change Task and Finish Group for their interim report - plan is now look at the recommendations and bring a paper back to future #RCGPCouncil for discussion

.@MartinRCGP updating #RCGPCouncil on some of the key policy developments since last meeting - lots of engagement with the DHSC ministerial team since the General Election; also College very supportive of the latest GP contract with thanks to @BMA_GP for work negotiating it
#RCGPCouncil member: I love the idea of some sort of app that links GPs with similar interests and they can learn from each other via that route

#RCGPCouncil member: what we are lacking is time to sit and talk to colleague - discuss what is important and gives working in general practice a sense of 'home'. We shouldn't need to go on a course to call it CPD - perhaps we need to de-professionalise CPD
#RCGPCouncil member: it's important to join learning/support networks up

#RCGPCouncil member: many newly-qualified GPs ask for experience with financial management and leadership, but it's important not to lose our way - sometimes it's a case of knowing what we want and not what we need
#RCGPCouncil member: it's important to know what opportunities are out there, so to go for them, and providing support with that
#RCGPCouncil member: we should turn appraisal back into a formative assessment; we have too much leadership in the NHS and not enough followship
#RCGPCouncil member: need to start referring to/distinguishing between personal professional development as opposed to professional development
#RCGPCouncil member: we have a problem in how we train GPs - often not supported well post CCT, and we should develop support services for newly-qualified GPs
Paper on Professional Pathways for Members being discussed at #RCGPCouncil
#RCGPCouncil member: #dearcolleague could be followed by shadowing - many secondary colleagues have no idea what goes on in general practice, and shadowing could give them insight
#RCGPCouncil member: @RCGPVoT have developed a video with similar messaging to #dearcolleague on how to improve primary-secondary care interface
#RCGPCouncil member: so many of the professional issues we have could be overcome with better communication - #dearcolleague is a positive way of getting the message across
#RCGPCouncil member: #dearcolleague needs to be part of an NHS leadership model - everyone in the NHS, regardless of their role, need to be kind to one another
#RCGPCouncil member: medical schools are taking denigration very seriously and medical students are encouraged to whistle-blow if they hear/witness it
#RCGPCouncil member: mutual respect is crucial to effective working - although if the College adopts #dearcolleague UK-wide, we should be wary of setting expectations
#RCGPCouncil member: #dearcolleague should be applicable to everyone working in the NHS, not just doctor-doctor relationships
Lots of support at #RCGPCouncil about #dearcolleague - many saying they have already adopted it or similar, following @rcgp_ni's lead

#RCGPCouncil member: it's time for respect, dignity and civility, and we all need to look at our own practice and whether any of us have said something derogatory about a colleague elsewhere in the NHS
#RCGPCouncil member: poor communication, lack of respect between doctors in different sectors can have negative impact on patient care - encouraged by success of @rcgp_ni #dearcolleague campaign
#RCGPCouncil member: surprising how more 'vicious' secondary to secondary care interface can be compared to primary to secondary care interface
#RCGPCouncil discussing 'interface principles' following the successful #dearcolleague work by @rcgp_ni @laurence903
#RCGPCouncil member: transparency is important, and clarity around the difference between philanthropic and commercial work re international work
#RCGPCouncil member: we should question whether College involvement in a country is strategically important to them, or strategically important to us
#RCGPCouncil member: the international workforce is incredibly important in supporting general practice at a local level in many areas of the UK

#RCGPCouncil member: should Council have a role in considering how it approaches work with individual countries, not international work as a whole - esp when there is a sense of urgency re College's involvement in some countries
#RCGPCouncil returns from lunch - now discussing the College's international strategy
#RCGPCouncil member: increasing pressure at a time when general practice is under pressure, the instant reaction re additional training to do an extended role will be to not do it
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to celebrate the GP generalist role, so should concentrate on that more than supporting specialist interests
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to acknowledge that there is a spectrum that differentiates the type of work we are doing in general practice
#RCGPCouncil member: there are many things GPs can do already, but we are now expected to do further training on in order to do it - counterproductive

#RCGPCouncil member: often GPs are just given the bits that other areas of medicine don't want to do and package it as giving them an 'extended role'. Extended roles should be more general eg care of homeless, care in care homes etc

#RCGPCouncil member: Extended Roles can be very important for maintaining GPs' wellbeing through helping to develop a portfolio career - but concern that any College guidance re GPwERs might end up being mandatory and linked to regulation
Next up at #RCGPCouncil a discussion on GPs with extended roles - looking at what the College can do to best support GPwERs
The RCGP's policy and campaigns priorities for the next three years will be reducing unnecessary GP workload and ensuring a sustainable infrastructure for general practice #RCGPCouncil
#RCGPCouncil member: if we don't have a 'doable' job we can't focus on other important things such as fighting health inequalities and tackling climate change
#RCGPCouncil member: good that the College's patient and carer partnership group was consulted as to what the policy and campaigns priorities should be

#RCGPCouncil now discussing what the College's policy and campaigns priorities should be for the next three years - for the RCGP to work on alongside @MartinRCGP's priority to reinvigorate relationship-based care
#RCGPCouncil member: important not to refer to it as 'the burden' of supervision of members of the wider practice team

#RCGPCouncil member: as a College we are doing a lot of work around how we can support new professionals working with GPs in general practice - conversations ongoing re how we support them, interact with them etc
#RCGPCouncil member: could inclusivity cover associate membership for members of the wider primary care practice team?
#RCGPCouncil member: strategy should reference that there is already work going on to promote inclusivity and diversity across the College
#RCGPCouncil now discussing the review of the College's Strategy for 2020-2023
Feedback #RCGPCouncil members will now be passed to RCGP Trustee Board who will make a decision on the College's sponsorship policy
#RCGPCouncil now undertaking several votes that will guide the Trustee Board's decision as to what College's sponsorship policy should be.
#RCGPCouncil member: red lines need to be consistent, from experience accepting sponsorship from private providers has increased ability to put on educational events and increased attendance

#RCGPCouncil member: the College's values should be at the heart of everything we do, if we give up on our values, we should just give up and go home. We should reduce slowly our income from sponsorship
#RCGPCouncil member: sponsorship of any type is a conflict, companies sponsor because they want something - we undersell ourselves when we offer trustworthy RCGP brand to the highest bidder
#RCGPCouncil member: there are often grey lines when it comes to sponsorship eg gambling/smoking industry funding gambling/smoking awareness. Transparency is key
#RCGPCouncil member: we must be careful about not appearing to denigrate colleagues who work in private sector by excluding sponsorship by private healthcare providers
#RCGPCouncil member: is it hypocritical to exclude overseas GP recruiters from sponsoring RCGP events, when UK looks abroad to recruit?
#RCGPCouncil member: wasn't felt pharma can be excluded completely at the moment but efforts should be made to reduce whilst being mindful many important events rely on it
#RCGPCouncil member: certainly behind the principle of transparency re sponsorship, but hypocritical to exclude pharma sponsorship but not from non-evidence-based nutritional products
#RCGPCouncil member: re retired members, it needs to be made clear why they are sometimes kept separate from other members at events due to pharma sponsorship laws
#RCGPCouncil member: to say pharma shouldn't be involved at all would be shooting ourselves in the foot, we should also be wary of excluding private sector. Decisions should be made case by case
#RCGPCouncil member: at Faculty level try to be robust re pharma sponsorship; don't think RCGP should support cosmetic surgery sponsorship or by non-evidence-based nutritional products
#RCGPCouncil now moving on to discuss the College's sponsorship policy

‚ÄúWe need to build trust, and that trust needs to be built at a local level. We need to build trust in new technologies as they are rolled out. How can we learn from the successes of past technologies?‚Äù #FutureVisionGP
‚ÄúWe need to be sure that as the tools become more complex they are still explainable to the doctor and crucially to the patient. It is essential to tackle biases in automation‚Äù @SarahDeeny
‚ÄúDoctors will never be replaced by machines but doctors who do not use machines will be replaced by doctors who do‚Äù #FutureVisionGP

‚ÄúAI can help patients be more in control, and empower them. We‚Äôve done a lot of patient engagement and AI can help patients understand what is happening in their care. This democratises healthcare‚Äù @IndraJoshi10 says #FutureVisionGP
‚ÄúAI helps us understand which interactions are important, and helps us understand which bits of the GP patient relationship are most important‚Äù @SarahDeeny @HealthFdn #FutureVisionGP
‚ÄúPatients themselves will be able to use data-driven tools to better manage their own health and their own relationship with their GP‚Äù says @wellcometrust #FutureVisionGP

That brings #RCGPCouncil to a close - congratulations to @MartinRCGP for chairing his first meeting
#RCGPCouncil member: need to be aware of and tackle negative connotations that might be associated with Fellowship

#RCGPCouncil member: another problem re recruitment of Fellows is a lack of self-esteem among GPs - it needs to be clearer what the eligibility is as some GPs don't think 20 years of dedication to patient care is enough
#RCGPCouncil member: need to look at application process and cost of Fellowship to increase number of Fellows
#RCGPCouncil member: need to consider what is in it for the person to become a Fellow, and what is in it for the College to have lots of Fellows
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to find a way to get through to groups who haven't historically applied for Fellowship
#RCGPCouncil member: Fellowship should not be recognition of leadership qualifications over clinical qualifications
#RCGPCouncil member: Fellowship should continue to represent a higher standard of membership to the College, but it should be more inclusive and accessible
#RCGPCouncil moving on to a discussion about routes to RCGP Fellowship
#RCGPCouncil now hearing an update on member numbers - and different routes to membership. Proposal is to set up a short life working group to look at introducing more inclusive routes to membership

#RCGPCouncil member: Junior International Committee aims to channel hunger of AiTs/First5s to have international experiences and promote general practice worldwide - essential College has presence worldwide as lots to be learnt that can benefit patients here & abroad

#RCGPCouncil member: we're so lucky to be working in the NHS, and we have a duty to promote primary care around the world - but we need proper market research and (ongoing) risk analysis before we enter into any new projects overseas
#RCGPCouncil member: we do need more GPs in the UK, but we must not target any countries that are also struggling with their doctor workforce. Recruitment needs to be ethical
#RCGPCouncil member: there are huge learning to be had from colleagues overseas, which can really help us in our daily practice

#RCGPCouncil member: concern around seeing international activity as a business opportunity as opposed to simply promoting primary care globally. Our activity needs to be evidence-based and in line with RCGP values - it also needs to prioritise UK members
#RCGPCouncil member: there is also a risk of 'primary care colonialism' that we should consider carefully
#RCGPCouncil member: any international activity needs to be seen through lens of risk to UK members that travel abroad on our behalf; to our members overseas; to the College
#RCGPCouncil member: we should check with our members, perhaps via a consultation, to ensure that our international work is a priority for them
#RCGPCouncil now moving on to discuss the RCGP International Strategy
#RCGPCouncil member: important when we talk about relationship based care that it is relevant to partnered, salaried and sessional GPs
#RCGPCouncil member: with an ever-changing health landscape, it might be difficult to keep track of what 'relationship-based care' means

#RCGPCouncil member: we know that continuity saves lives - but there are different forms. Should we be thinking of introducing relationship-based care as something that is present through the GP curriculum
#RCGPCouncil member: being able to build trust with patients over time helps us to have difficult conversations with patients when they arise
#RCGPCouncil member: it's key to recognise that relationship-based care also brings joy to GPs as well as benefits for patients

#RCGPCouncil member: one of the most powerful things we can do as GPs is nothing - to hold the risk, to ensure patients know we are there. Perhaps 'relational activity' as opposed to relationship-based care

#RCGPCouncil member: it comes down to access, and access to any member of the practice team can be limited - and we need to be able to organise patient notes in a way that can be accessed and understood by all members of the team
#RCGPCouncil member: patients do build relationships with other members of the practice team, not just GPs - and we should give the patient some choice over which HCP they would like to see

#RCGPCouncil member: most patients recognise the wider-practice team in general practice, but they are often assured when they know the GP is involved in their care, even if it is directly delivered by a different member of the team. It's about integration

#RCGPCouncil member: we need to pay a lot of attention to the patient voice when putting together a position on relationship-based care - but RBC is under threat and we need to highlight how cost-effective it is in order to safeguard it
#RCGPCouncil member: we would all like to practise good relationship-based care all the time, but sometimes with workload pressures, it isn't possible

#RCGPCouncil member: some of the hardest to help patients, who appear not want to change - there is huge satisfaction in encouraging them to make very small changes, but that is only possible because of relationships built with them over time

#RCGPCouncil member: anything that increases the number of transactions within a system and the fragmentation of the care delivered threatens this. High-quality research into benefits of continuity of care will help make our case

#RCGPCouncil member: implicit responsibility - whether you see the person or the patient, we have a responsibility to them, but we also have a responsibility to the system we are working within, and GPs are often the safety-net of that system
#RCGPCouncil member: is there an alternative to the term 'relationship' based care? This can sometimes conjure unhelpful connotations
Back from lunch and #RCGPCouncil is about to discuss relationship-based care
#RCGPCouncil breaks for lunch
#RCGPCouncil member: members should be central to the strategy but with a view to bettering patient care
#RCGPCouncil member: we need to clarify what the role of the GP is, especially with greater emphasis of the wider practice team, and the College's strategy is a good opportunity for this
#RCGPCouncil member: patients are the reason the College exists and need to be central to its strategy
#RCGPCouncil member: it's important that UK members are central to our strategy as they make up the majority of our membership, and need to see how valued they are by the College
#RCGPCouncil member: workload and workforce should be central to future College corporate strategy
#RCGPCouncil member: equity should be on the list of values included in the College's strategy
#RCGPCouncil member: inclusivity is key to future strategy - needs to be clear that there is a level playing field for any member to be involved in College
#RCGPCouncil member: important for strategy to make clear that GPs are specialists in general practice medicine; we also need to be clear that GPs are involved in many different communities

#RCGPCouncil member: future strategy should strengthen our focus on relationship-based care - it is our USP as GPs - and we have a role disseminating the importance of this aspect of our role across the health sector

#RCGPCouncil member: we maintain standards, we set standards, we encourage high standards of practice and it is essential this is reflected in any corporate strategy - and that we listen to our members
#RCGPCouncil now moving on to discuss proposals for the RCGP's 2020-2023 strategic plan
@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil votes overwhelmingly to pass both parts of the motion
@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: we need understanding about how the information on the DOI register will be used, by who, and the potential implications of this
@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: there are some security issues to consider, for example, someone may not feel comfortable declaring that they are a member of the armed forces
@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: it would be useful to have some clarity around the handling of DOIs - declaration is not sanitisation
@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: as well as declaring interests, there needs to be an explanation as to why an interest might lead to a conflict
@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: DOIs actually protects the individuals making the declarations...but we do need some guidance around what DOIs actually mean

@AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: there needs to be further discussions about what interests doctors would be asked to declare on a central register - financial, professional, faith? It can be murkier than it might seem.
#RCGPCouncil member: as the motion calls on this for all doctors, it is important @AoMRC is involved
#RCGPCouncil member: a central register would be very useful - we are one of the most trusted professions and this would help maintain our trust and integrity

...and that RCGP confirms its belief that all HCPs should make similar DOIs; that a central register could be used by others eg journals and employers to avoid duplication and save time; and that the cost of such declarations should be met by central Government #RCGPCouncil

#RCGPCouncil now hearing a motion for RCGP to call on GMC to ensure all UK-reg doctors make a declaration of interest as condition of registration; that they can update DOI any time & review at least annually; these are held on a publicly searchable register...

@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: legislation is important here as it would force government to introduce funding to, among other things, give parents the support they need to avoid using physical discipline
@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: we should note that this motion just brings children in line with adults - however agree we shouldn't be criminalising parents
@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: do we want to encourage legislation that will cause concern and confusion and gives the state ability be more involved in our family lives?

@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: children are among our most vulnerable patients and we should give them the care they deserve, and their parents the support they need to use non-physical disciplinary methods that will benefit wellbeing of parent and child
@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: it's important that any sort of restraint to keep children safe is removed from this discussion
@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: there are also situations where children face harm from those who are not their parents, and this should be taken into account

@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: context of situations is very important and not always known by observers - will this lead to an influx of people calling the police about situations they have witnessed, without knowing the context?
@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: there is a risk that backing this motion will alienate some parents, which could in turn lead to mistrust of GPs
@RCGPScotland @AoMRC #RCGPCouncil member: in 21st Century the use of any corporal punishment is simply unacceptable
#RCGPCouncil member: nb. this is already law in Scotland, and @RCGPScotland has been co-signatory to an @AoMRC Scotland letter in support of the move

#RCGPCouncil member: we have an explicit professional duty to advocate for the most vulnerable in society, so RCGP has a role here and is a chance for College to say physical violence is wrong at any level

Back from the coffee break at #RCGPCouncil - now hearing a motion from a Council Member asking for RCGP to formally adopt a position to support legislative measures to prohibit the defence of reasonable punishment with regard to children

.@ClareGerada - I‚Äôm not arguing against ownership, localism or flexibility. But currently, we are employed by the state - we have trapped ourselves with the partnership model, we think we have autonomy with it but we don‚Äôt #RCGPAC

We can make decisions in a partnership - we can offer 15 min consultations, we can release time to focus on leadership. No one told us to do that. Partnership will evolve, but it is important says @MikeRCGP #RCGPAC

I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll ever get to a point where there is only one model of general practice says @MikeRCGP #RCGPAC - all will have benefits and limitations, it needs to be what is right for local populations
A successful general practice service needs GPs, but research has shown we are the medical specialty most at risk of burn out and leaving the profession: delegate #RCGPAC
We need to make the job doable - we need to work our how to build the capacity in general practice to do the job we need to do. It isn‚Äôt simply about the partnership model. @jonathanleach13 #RCGPAC
We need to stop seeing the model - we need to look at what the needs are in general practice, and what appropriate remuneration for delivering that is: delegate #RCGPAC
We need to stop thinking about ‚Äò8 session jobs‚Äô - offer flexibility that isn‚Äôt always written down on paper but works for GPs and keeps them in profession: delegate at #RCGPAC
In Northern Ireland - it‚Äôs more important to own what we do than be slaves to the system. The problem hasn‚Äôt been partnerships, it‚Äôs the contracts we‚Äôve been tied to says @GrainneRCGP #RCGPAC
We don‚Äôt need mega-practices but we do need partnerships, and we need to keep them local - and do we need to limit the amount partners delivering NHS care can earn? Simon Gregory #RCGPAC
In Scotland we often find that the salaried model of general practice is not affordable - delegate enters the partnership debate #RCGPAC

.@ClareGerada now speaking against the motion: ‚ÄúThis house believes that the future of general practice lies in the partnership model‚Äù. It has served us well, but the partnership model is the root of the problems GP is facing today, we need a paradigm shift #RCGPAC

‚ÄúTech has been a massive thing during my time as Chair and we have a tech manifesto. There is so much we could do better if we get the basics right first‚Äù @HelenRCGP rounds off this year‚Äôs NHS Question Time. #RCGPAC
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been a mentor for years but what we can‚Äôt do is mandate it, it‚Äôs not a one size fits all‚Äù @HelenRCGP #RCGPAC https://t.co/sHXjdmgihf
‚ÄúWe all have a responsibility to look at how we look after people but with technology there‚Äôs no need for a mentor to be near you geographically‚Äù says Dr Rosie Benneyworth #RCGPAC

‚ÄúAbsolutely we need a mentorship scheme. And in terms of technology, the way we are working and our IT is one of the least efficient things we have. We need integrated notes and to be working on a system we can access from our practices‚Äù @jodieblackadder #RCGPAC https://t.co/EVUO5uNeew
Next questions: What do you think about the failed procurement in the NHS. And: Would it help to have a mentorship scheme?

‚ÄúWe are pushing to improve the level of resource for training across all four nations. We know that working together, there are excellent examples of how people can better organise training within teams‚Äù says @HelenRCGP #RCGPAC
Dr Rosie Benneyworth starts off: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be essential how people are supervised in these new roles and that they aren‚Äôt just being used to plug gaps.‚Äù #RCGPAC
Next question: With the increase of multi disciplinary teams, how can we help with the levels of training? #RCGPAC
Prod @HelenRCGP: ‚ÄúThese terms were set up with good reason - but those reasons are long gone and we are definitely behind the curve on this one‚Äù #RCGPAC

‚ÄúPeople find it confusing and I agree that we should lose these terms. It does lead to hierarchy within our structures and that does not help in the work we are trying to do‚Äù Rosie Benneyworth #RCGPAC
Dr Austin: ‚ÄúIn Ireland most part time GPs are women and there is an underlying sexism behind the terms. It is about confidence to stand as a GP and not how people view you‚Äù #RCGPAC
‚ÄúWhy are we creating division when we should be creating a sense of unity‚Äù @jodieblackadder #RCGPAC

‚ÄúYou come to my surgery you‚Äôre a GP is doesn‚Äôt matter beyond that. It certainly shouldn‚Äôt be a barrier to people taking on roles or responsibilities within a practice. GPs are GPs.‚Äù @HelenRCGP #RCGPAC
Next question: Does the college see a time when we stop calling salaried GPs ‚Äòsalaried‚Äô? #RCGPAC

Dr Austin O‚ÄôCarroll: ‚ÄúIn my opinion, people don‚Äôt really understand the effects of a border and the sense of division that will bring. That‚Äôs why the Irish are so set on this, because it had devastating impacts on communities in Ireland‚Äù #RCGPAC https://t.co/gYHoX8PrrY

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs so frustrating is that we can‚Äôt get legislation passed. Everything is delayed because of Brexit and I am frustrated and I know politicians are too. But there is no evidence that current medicine shortages are related to Brexit‚Äù @HelenRCGP #RCGPAC
Next question: To what extent is the politics breakdown having an effect on healthcare delivery- particularly on getting medicines out to patients? #RCGPAC
‚ÄúThe government should look at how we find this better but charging patients would affect the most vulnerable in society and that is absolutely not what we want‚Äù @Dr_Kasaraneni #RCGPAC

‚ÄúI believe a state funded health service free at the point of need is the most secure health service...but responsibility needs to be turned back to government to fund it correctly.‚Äù @Dr_Kasaraneni #RCGPAC https://t.co/3r5NF4dOMn

Next question: The NHS is lauded as one of the most lauded cost effective care services. With Brexit in mind, will the College call for a public debate about how the NHS is actually funded? https://t.co/2zFavtv3P0

‚ÄúIm a fan of PCNs and the concept but I do have concerns that they could be a distraction from the core work within general practice. Leadership is vital for quality of care. We need to be supporting our clinicians and helping them develop those skills‚Äù Rosie Benneyworth #RCGPAC
‚ÄúWe need more experienced GPs to be part of getting these PCNs up and running and for people to take a chance on that.‚Äù @jodieblackadder #RCGPAC
‚Äú...as a college we are trying to do that and help that continue‚Äù @HelenRCGP #RCGPAC

Over to @HelenRCGP: ‚ÄúIn good practices they‚Äôre already trying to look out for each other and don‚Äôt just talk about work but check we are all alright. It‚Äôs worrying if practices aren‚Äôt doing that... https://t.co/aEbDwn5RYX
Next question! ‚ÄúWith all the focus on PCNs and supporting new staff - how will you ensure sometime is done to specifically support GPS within the practice setting?‚Äù #RCGPAC

‚ÄúWe need to expand our teams so that we can provide good quality care‚Äù. Dr Krishna says having 15 minute consultations in his own practice makes a huge difference to patient care. #RCGPAC https://t.co/WIW1yokkpN
Over to @jodieblackadder- she says that medical students are drawn to the profession with compassion, and we need a more balanced way of consulting to protect care and continuity #RCGPAC
.@HelenRCGP says when you‚Äôre stressed and tired consultations take longer, and 15 minute consultations will help. We should be using our skills on those who need it
